column10: Great Game
Baaaaaaaaaaaa
ALL HAIL THE LAMB

Elements of Hollow Knight and Binding of Isaac are apparent throughout. They are also done in a beautiful and fresh new way allowing "Cult of the Lamb" it's own space at the table. I don't even like "The Binding of Isaac", but this game has made me willing to give it another shot. I am absolutely in love with this masterpiece.

I do have one con though...Your cult is damn near helpless. I constantly feel like I am on the backburner to keep up with it. There are a lot of QoL improvements towards the end of the game, but so many times I have felt my game progression stagnate because I have to get food, medicine, or gold. I feel like I have to choose between my progression of cult survival or the story. In my opinion the cult upgrades do a good job of rewarding me for my progression taking certain tasks off my hands. They don't do a good enough job keeping up that progression though. I am the GOD OF DEATH...WHY THE HELL DO I HAVE TO BUILD ANOTHER LUMBER MILL AND STONE MINE I HAVENT FIGURED OUT HOW TO KEEP THEM FROM COLLAPSING?!?!! Enraging at times man. Still a 5/5.

Looks so good on the steam deck OLED its stupid - Feels like it was designed for OLED devices. Has its comedic moments. The bosses are always "difficult" but beatable without having to face them 5 times.  Except at the end. The difficulty of the final boss is way higher than that of the others and will force you to grind through day night cycles to level up if you skipped all the pointless side quest requests - which i did not care for.

In my own opinion, Cult of the Lamb blends base building with dungeon crawling very seamlessly. Theres so much we still dont know and the world, but it's still somehow so fleshed out and well lived in. Theres so much to look into and explore, characters to get to know and learn more about, its amazing.

It can be a bit buggy sometimes, but as far as I know the devs are constantly working on patches and fixes. The base game itself is amazing, but we're still getting content updates (a reason to keep coming back !!) Plus even in the complete endgame you still have purgatory, or even just living with your followers in your cult. 

 I'm a big fan of the art style, a bigger fan of the soundtrack. I've probably got more hours listened to the soundtrack than I do hours in the game. I highly recommend!!!

I¬¥ve played 100 days in this game and just finished the main story. I was even contemplating to get all achievements but I won¬¥t and here¬¥s why:
- there are maybe 10 aspects in this game which are actually unique
- of these aspects maybe 3 are fun (the fighting, the dice game and caring for your cult to an extend)
- a lot of times it¬¥s repeating the same 5 things to advance in the game
- without the arbitrary hurdles to advance the actual game would be maybe 2 hours long depending on your skill
- you can¬¥t leave your cult alone for 1 minute which prevents from playing the actual game instead of babysitting everyone. 
- a lot of mechanics get introduced way too late in the game, like for example the sin mechanic. You need way too much to unlock everything and it takes way too long to get the necessary amount.
- there are many bugs which feel so frustrating. One time 2 of my cult members were drunk and shortly before they sobered up and I went to bed they started fighting. So I woke up and one of them died. Or for example half my cult just get stuck on the spot while trying to head to their beds. You have to talk to everyone to unfreeze them so they don¬¥t get to be tired the next day.
- way too many actions have the same button mapped. I butchered way to many dead members because I missclicked or used my cursed instead of selling the old one.
- why is the "y" button used twice on the rhythm game? 
- fishing feels useless because the amount of time you need to fish every available fish that day takes too long and the reward is compared to other methods too little
- the game feels in almost every part too easy and when you get damaged it feels undeserved (for example the mob just spawned in or you can¬¥t see the attack because the environment obstructed the view)
- on the topic of difficulty: how should I know at the start of the game what difficulty level I should pick? yes you can change it later on but I gain nothing from it so for what reason should I put it anything higher than normal? And if you want a challenge, the more reasonable modes only get unlocked after clearing the main story and even for that you have to start a new save
- caring for your cult feels like work after some time. Had a chain reaction once because I had 3 newborns who shit everywhere which made my other members throw up

tl;dr - the game is a min-max simulator, still has a lot of frustrating bugs, way too many repeating parts and important mechanics come in way too late
The game wants to be way too many things at once. To juggle everything at the same time hinders the fun. Save to say I still could find some enjoyment but because of the things listed above it¬¥s sad to see what the game could¬¥ve been...

Cult of the Lamb is a definitely a fun game that provides hours of entertainment, but sadly I felt it wasn't as fun as I was hoping it would be, and it overstayed its welcome a little as the endgame started feeling pointless and repetitive. I still enjoyed my time with it, and I'm sure I would have been utterly blown away had my expectations been lower, but the overwhelmingly positive reviews got them a bit too high.
I'll explain more in depth:


[h1]What exactly is this game?[/h1]
It's an action rogue-lite mixed with a colony management sim. You go on "runs" where you fight enemies to gather followers and resources, and then you go back to your cult and use those resources to grow and expand it, perform rituals, introduce new doctrines, and generally just manage your cute animal followers. Or sacrifice them for more power. Either way, the goals are the same - go on runs to grow your cult, manage your cult to make yourself stronger.


[h1]Strengths[/h1]
For most of the game, the balance between the two gameplay elements really works. Your cultists start out completely incompetent, so you gotta avoid leaving them for too long, so you really gotta consider how long you want your runs to go on, as the risk of death is far from the only problem with continuing too far. You gotta make sure your cult is as prepared as possible for a long time without their leader before you go out, and then you wanna gather as many resources as possible as quickly as possible so you can keep expanding when you return.
Your followers can starve, get sick, grow old, kill each other, dissent against you, and more. You always gotta keep an eye on what's happening back home, and when you're back home you're eager to fix everything so you can head back out. It creates a very enjoyable loop that'll make time go by ridiculously fast.
Other than that, the art style is great, there's a lot of fun humor, you sometimes have to face pretty tough choices, and the fact that you have several different ways to build up your cult means there's some replay value.


[h1]Weaknesses[/h1]
Like I said at the start of this review - things kinda started falling apart by the endgame. I didn't find the action gameplay itself all that great -
[olist]
[*]It's a little too simple - there aren't that many weapons, abilities, or enemy types, so it doesn't take very long before you see all there is to see.
[*]It's a little too easy. I'm not claiming to be some incredible gaming god, but I just found enemy attacks extremely easy to avoid (with a few exceptions). They just telegraph them very obviously, aren't that fast, and you're invulnerable while dodging so it doesn't matter what direction you go. Just press the dodge button when an enemy is very obviously about to attack, and you're pretty much never gonna get hit. Cranking the difficulty to "hard" only gives enemies more health and you a little less health (plus a few other things like followers aging faster, but that's hardly noticeable) which isn't much of a problem when you're rarely getting hit. (The first time I died, it was on purpose to see what happens. The second time, it was on purpose to get back to camp. The third time I really did f*ck up and got myself killed. The fourth time was during the final boss where I came in really unprepared. That's it, I only died 4 times. I've never played a roguelike where I died so rarely in over 25 hours)
[/olist]
And with the action gameplay itself not being that great, the thing that really kept the game so engaging was the need to balance the action with the management. So, once I've reached the point where my cult was fully upgraded (which happened quite a while before I reached the final boss, as I spent more time managing my cult than I did on runs, since it was more fun), the appeal very quickly dropped. The cult was pretty much completely self sufficient. I had nothing left to do at my home base, and so my favorite part of the game basically just vanished in an instant. What followed was a series of quick runs where I didn't even bother collecting resources or anything, and I just rushed through it to reach the end and get it over with.
The game could have really benefited from a longer cult-expansion tree. More buildings, more doctrines, more rituals. Enough to keep the separate gameplay elements balanced until the very end.
With this being the case, even though I spent most of the game thinking I'll do another playthrough to see what happens if I develop my cult the opposite way, I don't see myself replaying it.


Other issues - Follower quests are fun at first but start repeating themselves quite early on (how many time can you make a cult member eat poop before it stops being funny?), there was an annoying stutter that appeared after running for a long time on the Steam Deck (fixed by restarting the game), and some things took a little too long to unlock (I unlocked the tailor very close to the end of the game, and couldn't care less about what outfits my followers are wearing by that point).


[h1]Final thoughts[/h1]
I had a good time with it, and would recommend it to anyone who wants a simple, casual experience that's addictive but also easy to drop in and out of. I do think it could have been better though - much better, even - and it wouldn't take much to get it there... so, I guess the fact that it's so close to being great but isn't quite there is a little disappointing.
Love it!

This game has been a time sink. I found the management of my little cult to be equally as stressful as it was entertaining and if it had ever been too much I was aware of a variety of options to make it a little easier. The art for the game is also very cute... mostly.
I would warn though that even after enabling available light sensitivity options it is still quite taxing on the eyes.

The main story is relatively short but there is a large amount of post-game content that allows for some continued play without pointless repetition, though admittedly many of the gimmicks are kind of obnoxious in this post-game.
A large portion of achievement hunting later comes down to RNG, so if your goal is competition then you will have to deal with a fair bit of slamming your head into the wall for chance encounters.

Another one of those games that gives you just enough of everything to do at just the right pace to keep you hooked. Cult of the Lamp delivers on each aspect of the game, giving us another Devolver classic.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just, watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. loaded into the game, made my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. loved it as it was the best time had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

I was lost and alone, without a game to play, having tried so many games that didn't satisfy my soul. Then Cult of the Lamb invited me in. Such beautiful scenery and such exhilarating combat! The more I played, the more I became addicted to the satisfying loop of killing nonbelievers, building up the cult, and getting stronger. But then I started to notice some things. Every day, chores (and bodies) just kept piling up, and that got repetitive after a while. Also, I was given just three hearts with no way to get more, and even the slightest mistake on my part would result in those being taken away as punishment. Finally, I got taken to some kind of frog deity who rapidly devoured my hearts, almost as if I were being sacrificed or something. Again and again this happened, until one night I'd had enough and decided to escape.

This is one of my favorite Rogue-lites. As a Rogue-lite it combines the entertainment of exploring randomly generated Dungeons, and being able to restart after being slain with the means to improve oneself, combined with the ability to customize one's character and grow, and comedically, the ability to customize, improve, and grow, is based entirely around the player's homebase, one's own Cult, where one tends to their Cult and grows in power before every single Dungeon run. The player's growth in power also is impacted by how the player directs and orders their cult into service. There is even loads of minigames, easter eggs, and secrets in this game. It is very enjoyable. I love this game.

I am editing this review to be more thorough, because at the time of writing this, I have achieved godhood. I am by no means a completionist- in fact, this is the only game I've ever 100% completed- but this game owns my heart. It's been the only thing on my mind for months, I've been constantly thinking about it, I'm obsessed! The combat is fun and intuitive (especially on a keyboard) and the little 'animal crossing' sections as i like to call them are incredibly relaxing. the music is vaguely creepy and wonderfully pretty, the art is beautiful, and all the followers (and the lamb) are super cute!! I've been planning to buy merch for a while, too. All in all, brilliant game.

Someone looked at animal crossing new horizons and said, "there's not enough demonic cult activity in this game" and I absolutely love them for it. Keeping tabs on followers while crusading is quite nice, as now the followers can kinda 'take care of themselves'. My one problem with the game is the fighting. 

  Its just flat out easy for a rouge-like. Its even a little strange as well, given how you cant look directly up and down when attacking. You get over that though pretty quick to be honest. But that doesn't help that there's really no versatility or flexibility in the tarot card you collect on your adventures, they hardly let you build off of anything outside of having more health and attack power. However I think its pretty easy to see the devs strived more for quality of life than combat. 

  Since the "relics of the old faith" and "sins of the flesh" content updates, all other problems I had with the game were fixed, taking my old score of 7/10 strait to a 9/10. I hope we see more for the game in the future.

This game was an interesting psychological experiment. I have zero interest in joining a real cult, or starting my own. At times the game made me feel ill to play. I feel this game is a deterrent to joining a cult because I doubt many people want to live in grass huts, eat poo, and let their selves be constantly abused by some leader or other members. This game offers you to think skeptically about things like virtues and what those mean and HOW they mean different things to different people. That's very relevant in the real world because many people like to advertise in ways like saying "We have integrity!". Cult of the Lamb may prompt you to reconsider religion, culture, and anywhere there is some "leader" or "more powerful being/force" than you. I would not like to play this game around too young of an age, but I know there are probably kids out there playing this. I do enjoy the artstyle and the gameplay mechanics. The fighting in this game is often very satisfying. As someone who was raised in a church that preached to me that I was less than human or good for being born a female, I am surprised to find this game as an outlet for so much aggression that I keep in check. It's also satisfying to see things like "sermons" and "blessings" and "prayer" being ran through the mud in this game. So in that sense, this game is very enjoyable. And yet it makes itself disgustingly honest enough for me to not want to attempt to be a part of a cult.

[h1]One of the Best Rogue-like/lite in the 5 past years. [/h1]

Honestly, there is so much to say about this game that I don't know where to start...

- Visual is amazing and full of tiny details, it's just impossible to notice all of them the first time you play it.
- The music are great too and perfectly fit a game like this with this kind of spirit and mood.
- Don't let the art make you though that it's a game for kids, it is not!
But the game-play loop, the art and the story and all you can do in this game, all together create some weird perfect combo for a game like this.
- Replay value? yes there is
- Easy game ? yes if you select the easy difficulty, but there is a real challenge otherwise, and you can even try the don't starve collaboration/event mode where the lamb need to eat and sleep, and on top of this with a perma-death if you die from one of theses.
- there 4 main Dungeon, (biome) with their own resources, monster, visual, special things etc.
Story boss put aside, there is other bosses who sometime could look like an other one but for the most part, they are and unique.
- The number of weapons, spells, skills etc is large enough to let you play like you want.

- The follower and Cult management could be a stand alone game itself, it's like a colonies game in the game, but don't make me wrong, it's not a "mini useless game".
And a very good point is that you can spend a lot of time in all of this, creating a big cult of 30 followers or more, and make use of each tile in this area and customize it.
Or... you can just do the minimum and focus on effectiveness and rentability and not talking so much care of it.
You aren't forced to spend more time than you want, and for players who don't like this kind of content It's a good point.

- And I just scratched the surface... there is too much to say, so many positive stuff, good ideas, and well executed!

- Ho! just a work about accessibility, in this game there is Time, and when you are in Dungeon, the Time isn't paused for your follower in the cult area, but there is an option to make the time freeze during dungeon for players who don't like this.
-An other good point, there is a special police for Dyslexic people, it's rare to see this and I'm somehow concerned by this.
- There is more options, I will not list all of them, it's just to say that this game have some options for peoples who could need it, and you can turn them On or Off as you like.


[u]There is only two negative point for me:[/u]
- First, the middle of the cult area isn't customizable, it's not a real problem, but the ground is full off mud and grass, and if I want to use the Gold floor everywhere, I will still have this island of mud in the middle... it's ugly, and if I can understand why they didn't let us put building or decoration there, I don't understand why the floor have to stay the same :/

- Second, the "wall" around the cult area can't be changed.
Now with the most recent update (sin of the flesh), we can customize the inside of the temple, and if we want to try to make the cut area fit in the same mood, we can, but only for what is on the floor.

It would be a good thing to not stop there and let players go a little further, I'm sure you can make a few background inspired by the different dungeon or else and let us choose between them ^^


In conclusion, Cult of the Lamb is maybe a perfect game, and it's again a proof that big company aren't where to look for if we want innovative games, with new concept or more.

A Big Thanks to Massive Monster Team, you made an amazing game and I'm happy to have seen it and be able to play it.

I dropped it without finishing.

The animation is nice, the art is nice, the concept is great and visuals are amazing.

The gameplay loop is bad. In the beginning it looks like it is gonna be a relaxing roguelike. Then it turns out that the village you build along with followers demand your constant attention, want to drown you in mundane chores and your ability to automate annoying tasks is extremely limited, and then it turns into one huge annoying and increasingly more irritating chore. You keep shoveling poop till the end by the way.

Around the 3rd boss someone had an amazing idea to make it into bullet hell so relaxing roguelike thing goes out of the window. Obviously when you effortlessly defeat first two bosses and get stuck on 3rd, something's off with the design.  Weapons you get at beginning of run are random, that means you can get stuck with a poor weapon, then good luck finishing it. The more weapon types you unlock, by the way, the higher is a chance that you get something bad, as number of possible weapons grows. So, heavy RNG.

I once described the game "Hell Architect" as "the cutest game I've ever played that allows you to feed people their own excrement." I can happily declare that Hell Architect has been dethroned - Cult Of The Lamb is the new king of cuteness-meets-coprophilia. 

A darkly cynical cult management sim combined with a very fun roguelike, Cult Of The Lamb has such a very unique tone that oscillates between "adorable" and "hardcore Lovecraftian horror" (with occasional detours into icky scatology) at remarkable speed. The result is bizarre and macabre in the best possible way. 

The visual design is absolutely brilliant, the game is a blast to play, and the dark sense of humor underlying it all is greatly appealing. I wholeheartedly recommend Cult Of The Lamb!

I am a 55 year old biker and trucker father, and probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 15 now. My son got this game from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 12 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he let me borrow his controller. Me and my son then played in turns and I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my son many happy memories.

I've beaten two bosses (Three at the time of writing the 2nd paragraph) and so far I adore this game, but i've found out (From an 8 month old video, let me know if that's changed) that if you run out of followers, you have two in-game days to get one or your save file is erased. This should be told front and center in the store page, or at the very least, when getting your first follower.

The game is showing some cracks too. Quests given by people outside of your cult gives you a Fleece piece, which apart from making the game harder (Apart from the Golden Fleece, which does make the game harder but with a good advantage in return) there is no point in doing so. Or unlocking certain Tarot cards (Gameplay modifiers, by certain I mean something like 'Break rocks on touch') makes the chance for each card spread more and more for bad ones, and you only get two choices each time you obtain one in a run. This could ruin Permadeath playthroughs, which are unlocked once you finish the game.

You get more useful Fleeces unlocked once you finish the game and can use them in the endgame content, but it was 20 hours without caring about Fleece pieces, and Fleece pieces i've used on useless ones when I didn't know useful ones existed.

If you're playing Penitence Mode or Permadeath, not using the Quick Start option bugs the difficulty, and Penitence Mode disables most of the scenes and dialog between The One Who Waits and the Bishops. Wish you could choose if you want this or not, since I came back from August 2022 I wanted to see the story again.

The artstyle and the music is pretty good, and i enjoy the theming, but it is a fairly pathetic game in terms of combat, which is more than half the game. 
The enemies are simultaneously simple and a little too easy to fight, yet whenever you are hit it is frustrating. the attacks are poorly choreographed and the hitboxes on both enemy and player attacks are poorly communicated. The artstyle, while beautiful, often fails to properly signal the difference between decoration, obstacles and enemies within runs. In general the game just has poor visibility and readability, and the constant dark filter in some stages doesn't help. movement feels ok but it is a slog backtracking through half the stage you have already completed to get to another room. often the best strategy to beat bosses is to run up to them and spam click while tanking the boss' own attacks. the tarot cards (main semi-permanent upgrades within runs) vary extremely between power, and the lack of choice within runs on the cards you can get means i was sometimes considering not unlocking new ones so as not to have a higher chance of drawing bad cards. 
I also encountered several bugs, some that were fairly game breaking. I have a fairly good gaming setup and the game often has lag spikes mid combat when nothing else is particularly running in the background. at least on two different occasions i have been softlocked, and once the game just crashed after beating the final boss, without allowing me to save. 
I don't know if that was purposeful, but overall it left a bad taste in my mouth. it is a mediocre action game with a fairly good base building element incorporated, but in a lot of ways it is unpolished and not really worth my limited time alive on planet earth. (and possibly more importantly, my limited wallet.) I can see other people enjoying this game, but I can't honestly recommend it - at least in its current state.
TLDR: Like, it's not bad, and i did end up playing until i beat the boss, but unlike other games of similar genres i have no desire to replay at all, and i find it hard to believe I will remember the game or its story long into the future. It's definitely a pretty game in a lot of ways, but it is mechanically and thematically boring and mediocre.

Cult of the Lamb is an absolute standout, easily one of the best games I've played in a long time. This game takes the concept of cult leadership and turns it into a wildly unique and captivating experience that's both darkly humorous and deeply engaging.

From building and managing your own cult to exploring beautifully bizarre environments and engaging in combat, Cult of the Lamb offers a rich and varied gameplay experience. The art style is striking, with its mix of cute and creepy elements, and the storyline is compelling, keeping you hooked with its twists and turns.

What really sets this game apart is how it blends strategy, action, and simulation elements so seamlessly. Managing your cult requires a careful balance of resources and follower loyalty, while the exploration and combat portions are thrilling and challenging.

In summary, Cult of the Lamb is a brilliantly crafted game that offers something truly unique. It's a game that's hard to put down, thanks to its engaging gameplay, intriguing storyline, and distinct style. Definitely a must-play for anyone looking for something out of the ordinary. It's a solid hit in my books!

I absolutely adore this game and had a blast completing all of the achievements. The music is amazing, the art style is super cute, the combat is fast and fun, the base building is great, and the progression is super addicting. I have been playing this game since launch and it's very exciting to see how much it has grown-- bug fixes, new content, new features, more customization options, more end game content, etc. This game really has it all.

I've never been one to play games like this, but the cutesy art style had me interested initially. So I bought Cult of the Lamb and decided to give it a shot.

I was immediately hooked to say it simply. The dungeons are randomized, making every run unique and never becoming boring. The dungeons do definitely have a difficulty spike, but you can remedy this with some practicing and strategy. The taking care of your cult aspect is fun since you can customize just about everything to your liking. You can also interact with your followers which is personally my favorite thing to do. 

And the music? It's heavenly. Massive Monster definitely made the best decision when they had River Boy make their music. It's so unique and stands out compared to the soundtracks of other games. I sometimes go out of my way to enter dungeons just to stand there and bop to the music, it's just that good!

Overall, you should absolutely buy this game if you have the chance and the money, it's a must buy for sure. 10/10

An absolute must-play for any fans of the genre. Even if you're not a fan of the genre, I can almost guarantee you'll enjoy this game

Do you like cute anthropomorphic animals? Do you wish you could take them all home? Do you want to gently care for them when they're sick, lovingly make them meals, and build them special comfy beds? Or, alternatively -- do you want to make them eat poop, put them in prison for no reason, and occasionally sacrifice them to a giant tentacle for being annoying? Well, this game has all of that!

There's a nice balance between micromanaging/caretaking and battling/scavenging. If you want to give your most special followers a unique outfit (which helps a lot with your overall cult happiness!), then you need to do some crusades (scavenges/battles) to gather the materials. If you want a strength boost in crusades, you need to spend time helping your followers level up so they can become powerful demons to assist you. It's very intentionally balanced so each activity supports the others.

This game has excellent accessibility settings. I LOVE that you can entirely disable the timing-based minigames, especially for fishing. You can also customize the screen shake, depth of field, and chromatic aberration, so if those kinds of effects bother you, no problem! I hope more games add accessibility settings like this.

Cult of the Lamb is awesome, one of the greatest games I have played in the last decade, and of all time. 
The art is cutesy, detailed to surprising levels of sophistication and the animations all flow very well, improving more and more with each update.
The music feels perfect for each and every setting you come across and adds to the overall upbeat feel of CotL
The gameplay is kickass, it's fun! The combat is smooth and easily learned but some enemies and elements of gameplay are a bit more intricate to master. The cult aspect (especially since the new update "Sins of the Flesh") is also lots of fun, interacting with and managing your cult can absorb tonnes of time without you re entering a dungeon and you can actually grow slightly attached to the charming recruits you will surely come across. 
The story is interesting, and as the game grows things only continue to improve!
Thank you Devolver! ==Brandon

Diving into "Cult of the Lamb" was like stumbling upon a wacky infomercial at 3 AM; you know it's absurd, but you can't look away. The pitch alone had me scratching my head - a lamb leading a cult? It's like someone threw darts at a board of "least likely leaders" and hit the jackpot. Yet, there I was, captivated by the bizarre allure of orchestrating my own fluffy-led doomsday cult.

The game's uncanny ability to draw you into its woolly, sacrificial world is nothing short of black magic. As the story unraveled and my cult grew, I found myself gleefully navigating the fine line between divine shepherd and baa-d influence. It's a rollercoaster ride where you're not just along for the ride; you're the one laying the tracks, and somehow, the train is both on fire and serving refreshments.

"Cult of the Lamb" isn't just a game; it's a masterclass in how to make following a lamb into the abyss seem like a reasonable weekend activity. By the end, you'll be left wondering whether you've been entertained, enlightened, or simply ensnared in the game's fleece-lined trap.

This game is honestly one of my favorites. If you like roguelikes, survival sims, management sims, or anything similar... You'll love this game. It has a very satisfying gameplay loop between the crusades & cult management aspects.

Not to mention, it is INSANELY cute. The little noises the cult members make are adorable, & the art team on this game has done an amazing job combining creepy cult elements with cute little animal guys. The themes blend seamlessly visually and auditory. I have nothing but compliments for the art & sound team!

The game does have a couple glitches here and there, but I've been playing this game on and off since 2022 and it hasn't bothered me a lot. I haven't run into any glitches in 2024 that breaks the game fully, only minor annoyances. (Although I acknowledge they probably still exist...) There's also a lot more postgame content now due to the free updates, and the devs are pretty good about fixing bugs regularly. 

Overall, fantastic game and fantastic development team. Praise the lamb.

I just want to start off with, you should play the game for yourself. 
There is a lot of things that I enjoyed about the game, but first ill start with the devs. The devs actually care about the game. Rare, I know. Just today at the time of writing this, lots of people were complaining that one of the achievements that you had to get after completing post game, was extremely hard to obtain as the room that you needed, barely spawned in [spoiler] meat room [/spoiler]. They actually changed it, and I was finally able to get it to spawn and finish all of the achievements. Besides that, the game play, is good, at the start it will seem confusing and like you can't keep up, but after a few runs and upgrades, you will get it down. The art is fantastic, I enjoy the 2D/3D art of the game, and it shows how much more they could do with the animations of the characters with them being 2D. The one thing that I found annoying was not being able to get descriptions of quests. Some of the times I would skip dialogue and a random quest would show up, which you can't even get a description for, so I have to search in the wiki how to do it. The bosses are easy but also challenging in different ways. 
This game is a roguelite, so it is random every time you go in to the dungeon, which is good and bad. It provides a random different experience every time, but sometimes you are a lot more powerful than others, and it feels kinda luck based with powers you will get. In general it is balanced, but for some of the achievements, I would keep resetting to get a good run to complete them. 
Overall 8/10.
Just needs some improvements with quests, such as descriptions if you click on them and small patches to random things that felt clunky. Otherwise, would be perfect.

[h2] If you think that this is a roguelike, IT IS NOT [/h2]

[b]This is a story about wrong expectations, the game is not that bad after all.[/b]

Heard quite a lot about this game. Like it's a decent roguelike, thanks the media, I guess, and, after trying Hades, I've decided to try this one, too.

[i]Oh, boy, how wrong I was, thinking that this game was about combat and adventure.[/i]

The game is positioned as a roguelike where you can also control your own cult. In fact, this is the game where you must build your cult with the opportunity to fight.

Most of the time you spend cleaning poops in the camp and feeding everyone. Of course, there are buildings, rituals, shrines, blah-blah-blah. And that's it, folks, that's the core gameplay. 

And, as I said a bit earlier, Cult of the Lamd is not a bad game! It's just a bloody (literally) Stardew Valley. 
Very nice visual style ‚Äî check.
Own farm with flowers and fruits and whatever ‚Äî check.
Reputation (kind of) system ‚Äî check. 
Mines to gain resources and ocasionally kill someone ‚Äî check. 

Art work is monumental, though. It's obvious from the promo materials, but inside the game every art element feels great. Work on impact and combat itself is also quite impressive. Really. It's a shame that this is just a small part of the experience. 

[i]Would I recommens this game? Of course![/i]
But only if you wish to play a farm simulator. Roguelike elements are the best part of the game, yet the smallest.

You can make poop soup and everyone's an adorable animal crossing character.

After initially being upset with the game, steady updates have changed it completely. This game has sufficient content for many hours of gameplay and mechanics are diverse enough for it to not get boring anymore. 
I include my old review here to showcase how much developers have improved on past issues, they optimised the game a lot. Running the game lately, I ran into no problems and way less bugs. The added content is not only cosmetic but adds to the main gameplay, story and building mechanics. Quality of life changes have been added. Content that was originally locked behind a Twitch connection feature has been made accessible ingame. This game has had an overall improvement being now more than double of what it was before in regards of content, playability and fun. Due to the new additions, it now can speak to different kinds of audiences and playstiles, being the Binding of Isaac-like we always wished for as well as a fun base builder with cult implementations. The astethics and world design are a big strongpoint that adds to the mix. 

Big recommendation!

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
[Warning: Outdated Review Below]
First game I genuinely wrote over ten bug reports each for a different bug. Everytime I boot the game it doesn't hold up longer than half an hour before deteriorating into an unplayable mess: I freeze in fights or spells do not trigger, the events also freeze, yet in camp it is way worse: I regularly find ways to bug myself out of bounds without trying. Followers are buggy, won't do their tasks or don't memorize relationships, the cooking pot grows buggy as heck when other processes go on in the mean time, that's why I don't even have stone mines or wood sheds anymore and don't dare to collect money from the shrines. The scarecrows do not show when they are filled or are simply ignored by birds even when in range. When I sacrifice a high ranked follower, the 3k gold output holds your game hostage for over a minute! or it just freezes and crashes instead. 
This game is a buggy mess and badly coded, also proven by it's enormous size compared to the assets and functions. 
By now it is clear that the developers do not know how to handle it themselves, given that some bug reports I rendered almost a year ago still are recent. My guess is the localisation on different hardware and ambition of adding content conflicts with the fixing they have long promised to get going with. Patch notes show integral problems solved, that are pathetic and shouldn't have been there from the get-go. Added content so far is so unseeming, that I didn't notice a change since I first booted the game shortly after it's release, the Halloween event added 10 minutes of no-brainer grinding.
And forget any sense of convenience or quality gaming experience. Everywhere I turn in this game, there are unoptimised or unnecessarily annoying parts, that could have easily been fixed with a little time and consideration. A giant quantity of missed potential. Not to mention that the content provided is way too short for the price, the experience doesn't even start before it is already over - and I played on different difficulties and made two different cults using all options given. You know, every half of an hour that it let me play before exploding.
Not to mention that solely cosmetic DLCs for a quarter of the initial price and Twitch connection features are shady a.f. 

This is a game I really liked the idea of and tried my best to get the most of. But the game itself has hindered me from continuing to play it. It is literally unplayable for me at this point. I do fulfill the requirements needed, plus the settings on all the lowest options, I prayed to a three eyed cat, did not temper with anything and had no mods ever installed. This game is as I bought it and it is unplayable. This is unacceptable.

First negative review, I've ever written. More salt than in the wheels of this games functions.

PS: Making integral parts of your mediocre gameplay skip-able is one of the worst fixes for bad gameplay I have ever seen. 
Instead of actively triggering fans and basking in praise, you could try to bug fix your mess. Or set the price to an appropriate of 1 Dollar.

Adorable colony sim with roguelite elements. Inspired by the classics, (Zelda series, TBOI and a bunch of other Devolver games), but also achieves so much. Lots of versatility when it comes to gameplay, you have these Binding of Issac-esque arenas with destructible environments and varying sizes and difficulties of enemies paired with these bullet hell driven boss fights, of course, sprinkled with those aforementioned roguelite elements. Then you head back to base and now you have a cul-, I mean, colony, to take care off, making sure they get fed, get some good shuteye, get them to praise the lord, become sacrifices and of course make them work for a living in your base. You can also travel to different areas in this small map that provide you with a gambling addiction, a fishing addiction, a shopping addiction and maybe you'll even find some cool secrets along the way. There is nothing all that bad about this game, it's really good and has some replayability to it. If I were to complain about something, it would probably be the boss fights, they all play the same up until the final fight; a lot of it is just dodging the same attack patterns while also avoiding the boss' peons, not really all that difficult despite how menacing the game makes them look. It's a small nitpick for me, I just really enjoyed the versatility on display but thought this could improve for maybe a future installment or a huge update. Cu-, Colony of the Lamb is truly amazing and offers a lot of bang for your buck, this will be another gold standard for roguelites in the indie genre. Praise the Lamb!

In all seriousness: This game is a heartfelt marriage of Animal crossing-esque village/town life, and Binding of Isaac roguelike combat. These two genres bring very different audiences, but Cult of The Lamb caters well to both: you can raise and lower the difficulty of the combat to suit your needs and what you prefer to focus on. 

The art style is adorable and simple: the sexual aspect is portrayed cartoonishly, and there is little traces of violent bloodshed. Hell, the only blood I can recall is on character designs. Speaking of: every design is adorable and thoughtful. My favorite character is Leshy: his boss music is groovy, his gameplay mechanics are appropriately simple as the first boss, and [spoiler] you can make him a follower! He makes THE CUTEST SQUEAKIEST SQUEAKS EVER. I have put him in the wedding suit and kiss that squeaky boi every day. [/spoiler] Also there is a short about him tryna cook, and it's so silly.

Anyway, the soundtrack is bop after bop. Every combat theme is filled with power and confidence. The cult area OSTs are adorable and sweet; that lust festival OST is a certified buns-shakin' beat.

I do think this game needs a bugs patch and general adjustment to quality-of-life. It would be so useful if we had a follower call system. Perhaps a way to summon them via the followers list. I also think a crowd-calling method to gather them (like a bell?) would allow us to easily bless/inspire/intimidate. 

Additionally I think follower quests should be weighted. Refusing a minor request (such as feeding poop to a follower...) should not impact faith as badly as, say, refusing a marriage request. It is comically frustrating to be forced into feeding my favorite follower poop, or murder my spouse, or build 3 decorations, simply because I do not want my followers to dissent. 

Anyway, this game rocks! If you are seeking cute animals sadistically dedicated to a satanic laugh, and spontaneous emotional attachment to a boss-turned-squeaking-bush, buy it, play it, love it and don't look back.

Cult of the Lamb is a treat to play. It's striking a good balance between the base building and action segments of the game. It's fun and I CANT STOP PLEASE YOU GOTTA HELP ME. ITS BEEN 35 HOURS AND THAT MUSIC AND GAMEPLAY IS HYPNOTIC. ITS TOO FUN.

Gameplay:
Base Building is solid and fun. Followers are like children you nourish and manage, but adds a layer of micromanagement that would catch some people's fancy. Combat is okay. I can see how latest DLCs have been slowly improving on it, but it's simple Roguelite mechanics make it fun enough to not anger you, nor to bore you. It's an okay balance.

Music:
It's been living rent free in my head for 8 days. I CANT STOP LISTENING TO IT. FR THE MUSIC AND SOUND DESIGN IS GOD TIER. LOVE THE MUSIC AND SFX TO BITS.

Difficulty:
It is easy for a bit... till you hit the endgame content. It gets a tad more difficult at that point and your reflexes are put to the test. It got better, I'll tell you that.

Overall, a solid 10/10 for me
PS: Love the Devs too. Fun bunch of people ^w^

I think its a good game but has some major faults. The actual combat portion of the game is S tier, I like the boss design, I like the enemy design, I like the curses and weapons and whatnot, the musics really good, the graphics are really good, its an incredible rogue-like experience. But for every 5 minutes of adventuring I have to spend 10 minutes doing unexciting chores around my base, like cooking, cleaning, blessing every cultist, working the fields (You can get assistance but they're not efficient enough), I have to do my sermons, I have to do my rituals, I have to go catch all the fish from the pier or else I'll not have enough food, I have to take quests from my cultists and then lose 25 faith because I won't let them eat poop, and then they dissent and cause all kinds of problems. I wish there was more of playing the game and less of that.
Very fun with cute Art!

This game was very cute, fun, and full of fast paced combat! It had a little bit of everything I love honestly.
I'm not much of a dungeon crawler player but the fighting in this was very smooth and quick without being janky, so it was very satisfying to fight the monsters. My favourite was definitely the final boss, it was a good balance of bullet hell and kiting without being so difficult that I had to redo it multiple times (Which I hate cause it breaks immersion). Building the cult was also fun, although it got a little grindy at the end but I think that's just because I died to the bosses a couple times and had overpopulated my town saving everyone I met. I'd complain about the price to gameplay ratio but you can just tell they put a lot of effort in for such a small developer, the graphics are stunning and the cult has a lot of funny dialogue so its definitly quality over quantity in my books.
TLDR:
Its pretty, its fun, its controls handle beautifully even on PC, it's playable even if you don't usually play fighters. Get it on sale if you want value or get it full price because honestly they deserve it! Hoping for more games like this in the future tbh

Honestly, It's way overhyped and overrated. It can surely use a negative counterbalance. If you are looking for a casual game get an actual casual game like Stardew Valley etc. If you are looking for a roguelike then get a roguelike with good combat like idk, Dead Cells or Isaac etc.

This game is a mix of taking care of your "cult" (more like daycare for cute anthropomorphic creatures) but your followers can't be left alone for longer than literally 5 min until you get the rituals to extend it to like 20. What do you do with that free 20 min? You mostly go into the dungeons to fight but the combat is very mid. Some enemies telegraph projectiles some don't, most weapons feel the same with fast attack weapons being FAR better than the slower ones. btw, you can only go through 4 stages at maximum, after that it's just going back home.

btw, difficulty levels are there but those also affect the cult so if you want your cuties to b**ch even more often than usual you can do that but it's just adding more busywork not real difficulty. In combat difficulty is just the usual HP bloat. Honestly after playing on hard for like 20h I switched to easy and never looked back.

imo if you want this just get it on sale and don't expect anything spectacular because the edgy cult stuff wears off fast and what you are left with is just 20 toddler-minded followers to babysit and doing mid dungeons on your breaks.

Wow. This game really impressed me. It was fun on PC, but where it absolutely shines is on Deck. This has been the first game that I've played that really felt all the way great on the Deck. There have been a lot of close-but-not-quites or good-except-for-the-controls, but this one nails every aspect. It plays better on a controller style, the crusades are mobile sized 5-20 minute format, screen size doesn't feel limiting, and there is more laid back management to do in between or if you can't commit to a crusade.

Just a really excellent game.

This game can be mostly split into 2 sections, crusades and cult management.

On crusades this is a rogue-like game. Similar to games like "Binding of Issac" and "Moonlighter". Fight a lot of enemies in a procedurally generated dungeon. Gain power-ups that can help you on that crusade and resources that can help you later. 

Outside of crusades you will have to manage your cult. This includes making sure your followers don't starve, have beds to sleep in, and do not lose faith in you. You may direct them to gather resources for you that will either benefit your cult or benefit you on crusades. If Stardew Valley had minions you could control, this is about what that game would look like.

There is a bit more to it, but that is what the majority of the game will look like.

The DLCs all add cosmetic stuff. They are NOT required to get 100% of the achievements. Get them if you like the game and want to support the developers. I got the Heretics Pack and I like it.

Missed potential.
Masterclass in game design and aesthetics (graphics, OST). Lacking in combat and writing. Play this is if you like being addicted to gameplay loops and having the game lead you to make the most fucked up decisions ever.

UPD: On my second playthrough and I reached a point where there is no motivation to do anything. Upgrading the base? For what? The variety of things you can do in your base and with your followers seems limited, even with updates -- surface level, visual. You just wait for upgrades to "automate" your base, this automation is boring, limited and surface level, too. There is no challenge in keeping your followers in good terms with you. I could use my followers for bonuses but what's the point if I can kill any boss in 5 seconds by spamming a spell on the highest difficulty?

Concept:
It's a game about becoming a cult leader, at first you care about your followers, then you start using them for your own cause, then you drug them up and murder them when they annoy you. And it always pushes you to do more.
Right from the start the game tells you: there is no story and no characters, except for the most flat and zero-dimensional ones. Later they seem to try to slap "lore" on top of it. The symbolism and ideas are quite cool sometimes. I think I could sum it up like this: There is nothing worth spoiling even if one wanted to spoil the game.

Gameplay:
Have a dozen small and immediate tasks to always keep you busy and engaged. Micro-managing your resources and followers is fun. Building and managing the cult is also fun. Once you get to your second playthrough and exhaust all the quirky quests and their shock value, it also gets boring.
Combat is generic and sluggish, but has a bit of depth to it. Also extremely easy, If you get a few cards or buffs and a correct spell you can literally just spam invincibility or tank bosses. Controls are crap, especially on keyboard.

Replayability:
You can get different cult upgrades and abilities, perma-death and other added difficulties. There is really only one path you can take when building a base, unless you like decorating A LOT. There is also artificial randomness to all decorative drops.
The hardest difficulty doesn't make the combat much harder, I think it increases wait times/costs for upgrades, lol, annoying. At least the bosses don't die in 10 seconds, upd: nvm, they still do.
After playing for a bit more, I lost all interest.

i played this game before either of the main two updates came out and I have to say that they made a huge difference in enhancing my enjoyment of the game. Combat feels much smoother and more enjoyable with the inclusion of the Heavy Attacks and Relics in Relics of the Old Faith, and Sins of the Flesh takes the base building aspects of the game and makes them feel much more complete. The mechanics aren't too deep, but Cult of the Lamb takes its base mechanics and manages to combine them to create a game I can play for hours after beating the postgame. The difficulty options are nice, letting less experienced players enjoy the game without getting frustrated, while providing some challenge on replays of the game.

This doesn't mean the game is perfect, by a long shot. Some of the mechanics feel out of my control when I'm playing. In particular, a noticeable lack of invincibility after being hit on crusades means you can go from full health to dead in a few seconds on harder difficulties, not to mention the absurd difficulty of the third major boss (how do you even dodge the three fireball lines in phase 1?) 

In my opinion, this game's main strengths come from the constant updates and the dedication of the developers to constantly improve the game. It went from a game I enjoyed at launch to something I play regularly after the updates, and I feel like it can get even better. I have to admit I'm not very good at ranking things objectively and without bias, but I love this game and think it's worth a shot if you have the money to spend.

I already bought Cult of the lamb on Ps5... and for my friend... and for another friend... the point is, I want people to experience this game. Its incredibly fun and perfect for those into cuteness juxtaposed with dark and sinister themes. Game play is addictive, well balanced, and satisfying. Creating your cult the way you want it is so fun. Do you want it wholesome loving, or twisted and brutally violent? Do you want to work with your followers, or have them with for you? I can play this game over and over and still find value in a play through.
I do have some criticisms though.
The new weapon the Blunderbuss is really bad. It feels incredibly weak and can be very frustrating to use. The reload mechanic makes sense, but it gets really annoying when I run out of ammo and try to shoot, just for the reload progress to reset. It sounds really fun on paper to try to time your shots and keep a rhythm to your attacks, but if you mess up once, you lose all momentum. That on top of its pitiful attack damage. ON THE CONTRARY, the blunderbuss is ESSENTIAL if you use the Fleece of the Berserker. Its actually overpowered with that fleece. The range keeps you safe from risking getting hit, and its ability slowing down time and increasing the range makes any battle room a breeze. With that said, the blunderbuss needs to be reworked a little.
The alcohol addition feels tame. Its very funny and I get enjoyment out of it, but it feels useless at times.
With all the new building additions the size of your cult feels very tiny. I constantly have to rearrange. I'm thinking of doing another play through without decorating my cult, which sucks to say because you can make some really cool looking cults. A size increase would be more than welcomed.

Overall, this game is great. Every update gets me excited. The developers obviously care for their game and continue adding additions that fans love. If you don't have it, I would recommend doing so.

[h3][b]Some Game Recommendations[/b][/h3]
[b]Similar Experience[/b] 
Dragon Quest Builders (It‚Äôs not a dungeon crawler but the management systems and religion references resemble both titles)
Moonlighter (Has similar system of going to dungeons at nights and managing your shop during day)
Dave The Diver (More polished gameplay and minigames and much more easy management system)
[b]Something Different[/b] 
Fabulous Fear Machine (Meta jokes of some dark occult appears in this game as well)
Palworld (The pal system and the pleasure of being evil the way using pals resembled pawn system to me)
[h3][b]Review[/b][/h3]
The Cult of the Lamp is a merge of dungeon crawler, craft and crew management game. The game presents pretty solid setting using religious themes with a satire telling. The conflict between cute visuals and vile attitudes of the characters actually works pretty well for the theme. Also, this blend makes the setting more fun to consume. The game starts with a scene of our dear lamb being a sacrifice for the elder Bishops. The lamb, who is also the last of its kind, has been chosen for this ritual and being victimised by the followers of the bishops. Right at the death moment of the lamb, the forsaken Bishop (One Who Waits) occurs in front of him and tells our character to rise and get revenge of him. Then our character comes back from death and slays the followers. That way our lamb starts its crusade against the bishops and we start to collect pawns to create our cult. With this basic premise the game sets our goal to kill the bishops and manage our cult.
As you can guess from the explanations above the gameplay consists of two separate parts. At one hand we are going to crusades against other cults. This part plays as a classic isometric action title with some bullet hell challenges. In these crusades our character can carry one weapon and speel. There are several types of weapons in the game. Also, few of them have some little gimmicks to vary the gameplay. But the most obscure difference between them is attack speed, damage output, and weapon reach which is kind of dull for this kind of gameplay which requires repetitive gameplay. This dullness presents in the skill department as well. There are few skill types. To decrease this issue developers tried to give some spice with adding some weapon and spell upgrades such as having a critical hit chance or poison possibility on hit that you can get during the cult management part. Also, there are tarot cards you can collect each run that gives some advantages to you. These tarots cards and weapon upgrades actually bring good variety for gameplay, but they‚Äôre not enough to keep the gameplay fresh after a while.
Each bishop has their own biome and their own three followers at their service. In each crusade we choose a bishop‚Äôs biome, that way we start to explore a randomly prepared map. These maps have some similarities to the ones you can see in Slay the Spire. This is a good addition to gameplay. Each stop in maps provides you a place to explore, shopping spot, healing spot or another event to explore. This way the difficulty of the runs or the materials you can get during each run changes depending on your choice. Bishops have servants (Mini Bosses) three for each. Which makes plenty of variety on the boss section, and worth mentioning.
The management part of the game has similar mechanics most of the same types of games has. You gather pawns and materials during your crusades for crafting new things and building a cult. Then you gain some buffs for your crusades. Each pawn has their loyalty and they also have a life cycle. To implement this life cycle, they included a day-night cycle. This also increases difficulty for the management, so some might like this. There is a build tree for you to get new upgrades, but you need to have some Devotion as a currency. The need of Devotion increases with each upgrade you make. As a result, it becomes tiresome at some point. This issue occurs for every element of the management part. So later the game suffers to let you get upgrades for the next run. As a problem these blooms during the mid game at most. During you have some decent number of pawns you realise you need to lookout for them, and to do this and go into another run you realise you need to automize some of the things like making food for followers. But it‚Äôs not that simple if you haven‚Äôt spent your devotion on this department. You also have a church to pray, do some rituals and some other things that can give some buff your cult, village management or crusades. 
Lastly, the team behind the game makes a decent thing to update it constantly with free contents. They added a kind of New Game+ mod after beating the game. Also, last update lets you make babies in the cult, so it doesn‚Äôt need to add anything more. Right? Jokes aside it‚Äôs definitely a fun addition and the team knows what goes nice with the theme. Another thing is there is a dice mini game that has simple rules and likeable that you need to play at least once if you played the game. In the end I really recommend this game to people who did like run based games, and want some flavour, to vary the game and do some other stuff in a single game.

Fantastic little game.

It doesn't bring anything new to the table. It wasn't the first to make a colony sim, or bullet hell, or horror theme + cutesy art style. However, using a combination of the three(and never leaning too hard into any aspect), Cult of the Lamb makes a fun and casual game that you can reasonably beat in a few days. 

I like the art style, which semi-downplays the eldritch horrors you're consistently exposed to, and the barely better living conditions of the colony you return to. Characters are interesting, wacky, and memorable. Making all the characters basically speak Simlish was a good call. I do feel like they leaned a bit too hard on poop jokes. 

The music is memorable and meets the style of the game. It fits in 90% of areas, except for boss fights. Combat with the Bishops and the final boss felt a little underwhelming, and I ended up muting music for those parts and putting on other OST's in the background. 

The bullet hell aspect has a good foundation. I normally don't play that genre of game, so I can't say much about it other than that I like it. Challenging, rewarding, fun, and not too punishing. 

The colony sim side of the game is relatively simple to it's peers in the genre, but keeping the good bits. Managing food, faith, and sanitation can be challenging, but become less of a problem as you gain more options. Doctrine is also made very well, with simple "one or the other" decisions driving just how you plan to be a leader. You could be the benevolent and beloved leader who guides hand in hand with your subjects, or a (as your boss suggests) a brutal draconian dictator who keeps their victims alive long enough to be useful and murder/eat/sacrifice them to a dark god when they are no longer. Gameplay significantly changes depending on what you choose. Also, despite their appearance, your subjects actually aren't rock stupid and require little handholding. You can order them to perform a job, but if there's no more work or were never ordered in the first place, they will (usually) find something else to do by themselves. 

I would recommend it if you're dipping your toes for the first time into the game genres mentioned above, or want a game that doesn't require tens of hours to become proficient in.

Combat is great, weapons level up, game is full of content that is related to the actual story itself, seemingly lasting for 80+ hours of content due to Purgatory Runs. Bosses are hardish, with right weapons, relics, and curses it's pretty easy to kill a boss. Dodge mechanic works well. Controller works good, but mouse arguably is easier for combat.

This game requires ALOT of time for Followers. It's easy to get distracted trying to Min-Max followers and eventually food becomes a huge issue. 

There's no casual way to get an abundance of food, so after 30 followers abusing Tier 2 scarecrows and Missionaries are crucial to even be able to progress the story without followers starving to death. 
 
Farms help as well and make sure to stockpile on bones. Name each follower that you want to appear first in Character Select Screen with a Numeral in the beginning of their name so that you don't have to scroll for them.

Jultymer was once a lost, frightened pig in Darkwood but all her worries have been chased away when the cult leader saved her and recruited her into his faction. She watched in awe as their small group turned into a very fearsome, powerful, and influential sect that slayed those who opposed the great leader‚Äînamely the four Bishops of the Old Faith and The One Who Waits. It wasn't easy and with every new follower indoctrinated, new problems arise and one of them is in a form of an otter from Anchordeep. Jultymer did nothing but obey and worship the cult leader without question, always lowering her head as she is naive and faint-hearted. The compassionate cult leader noticed this and reassured her time after time and when she finally found her voice, someone started hating her for it. Pamerbre, a hot tempered otter noticed the weak Jultymer climbing the ranks and it did not sit well with him so he started making her pay for it.

[i]Pamerbre looked at Jultymer, and in his eyes, she recognized a hate big enough, wide enough, and deep enough to match her own. A hate you could drown in like a vat of wine.[/i] The small arguments escalated into full blown fist fights but none of them were punished. The tolerant and tenderhearted cult leader can only sigh and break off the fight, but this cannot go on. One time, the leader was a little too late to get in between the two of them so Jultymer got injured badly, and while she was healing all she could think about is how to permanently stop Pamerbre's ill doing. She has a plan and all she needs to do is to ask the leader, a fight to the death! A fight pit ritual! This will settle everything once and for all. But the ever benevolent leader have different plans for the two of them. Instead of using violence, the cult leader decided to make them mates. Jultymer is utterly dumbfounded, speechless even and the same can be said for Pamerbre. The poor innocent Unique Corn was damned after he became stupidly drunk thrice just to extract his Sin, something that is needed for the mating ritual that was bound to fail. Oh, it did fail but the cult leader is very persistent so he tried, and tried, and tried again. This time the cult leader has gotten clever in extracting sins and from 0% to to 50% success rate, Jultymer and Pamerbre gave in and produced an offspring. A tiny egg that the cult leader adored. He couldn't leave the settlement for a while since the egg needed to be tended to but he didn't mind, he treated that egg as his own as it fully hatched into a child‚Äîa child Jultymer and Pamerbre didn't care for as they pick up where they left and that is to antagonise each other. As Pamerbre continue picking fights despite the cult leader's effort, he had to make a tough decision. A choice to sacrifice Pamerbre to reopen Silk Cradle, and with that, peace and order have returned in the community.

This is a "rogue-lite" or whatever that I keep coming back to again and again. Every time they do another update, I'm starting over on a completely new save file because "I can make my cult even *better* this time."

Don't get me wrong, the "dungeon-crawling" aspect of this game is e a s y. I play enough of these types of games to go ahead and start on the "hard" difficulty and frankly, if I do another save file/there's another update in the future, I'm going to try for the next-hardest. 

But I keep coming back to this one. While it may not have the depth of story that a game like Hades does, its graphics/art, mechanics, and sound/music design are all great, and despite having more hours clocked on Hades, I've only restarted Hades maybe twice. I've run into a visual or audio bug here or there, but nothing that makes things unplayable, and the resource gathering/dungeon loop while time still passes for your Cult is very satisfying. Unlike Hades, small crawls only last me maybe ten minutes max and then I'm spending at least if not more time at the base arranging and managing things and all in all this game just hits all the highlights of replayability for me.

"Cult of the Lamb" blends the excitement of action-roguelite gameplay with the intricacies of base management, creating a unique gaming experience all wrapped in a cute little lamb shaped package.

Pros:
-  The game consistently introduces new elements, keeping the gameplay fresh and engaging. This approach enhances replayability and maintains player interest over time.
- The combination of action-roguelite mechanics with base management elements offers a balanced and absorbing gameplay experience. 
-  The game‚Äôs art style is a standout feature, striking a perfect balance between adorable and ominous. The Dev team leans on this even in social media and does amazing! (CoL cartoon when)

Cons:
-  While the integration with Twitch adds a layer of interactivity and community engagement, it suffers from occasional glitches and connection errors that can disrupt the gaming experience.
- Although enjoyable, the combat system and base management aspects lack depth compared to other titles in similar genres choosing a more basic version of both instead of mastery of either.
- Some players might find the game's loop of dungeon crawling and base management to become repetitive over time, especially after the mid-game when most upgrades and features have been explored.

Conclusion:
 "Cult of the Lamb" is a commendable title that will delight players looking for an inventive and aesthetically pleasing gaming experience. I think it is very franchisable and I hope we get to see more come from this wonderful world Massive Monster made. I give it 18/20 Followers ready to sacrifice.

I was unsure about this one for a while, but having both played and fully completed it I just have to recommend it. It pulled me in by reminding me of a childhood fantasy of me and my friends all living in a little community together. Those fantasies never included cult stuff and sacrifice, though, haha.

The cult management side of the game is cute and fairly easy. You really do just organize a little village, really. You can treat your followers as resources to grow faster, but I didn't really do much of that and found the game works just as well without much of it. You can absolutely play and roleplay at your own pace in that regard.

The combat side of the game is very well done! People say it's similar to Hades, but I've never played that. Instead, I'll compare it to Darkwood's combat for anyone also in the beta of that. Everything feels viable and fun, whatever you're given, and it does get fairly challenging. Especially in the post-game. Even here, you can pace yourself however you like! I actually struggled with some boss fights because I was going too fast and should've slowed down to properly dodge some shot patterns.

I have almost 50 hrs on Cult of the Lamb but once I finish it and get all the achievements, I most likely will not start a new save file and replay it. 

Cult of the Lamb is like if Stardew Valley, Animal Crossing, Hades, and Moshi Monsters had a love child

The game itself is beautiful, the story is intriguing, and I love the way the characters are designed, but I personally am not a fan of the repetitive dungeon-crawling to finish the main story and side stories.  However, I LOVE the farming and base-building aspects, along with the small amount of fishing. You can also marry your followers, and they can have sex and create amazing baby followers who can really benefit your cult, but that's pretty much it. The repeatability is extremely low, but playing the game for the first time is a fantastic experience, and it easily became one of my favorite games in recent years

If you love dungeon-crawling games and all the aspects above, then I highly recommend Cult of the Lamb
