The amount of appalling s**t you can do in this game is unreal. Absolutely disgusting design. I created a dystopian hellscape of State-supplied food, medical care, funeral & religious services, luxury single apartments, and social welfare programs, all while enforcing a reasonable rate of taxation. Truly, the depravity of the Satanic knows no bounds. 

Memes aside, this game's actually pretty great. It's like a cute, scaled down version of Binding of Isaac, where you can lean into/out of the more f**ked up stuff. Like yeah, you can create a cannibalistic murder-necromancy cult if you want, but you can also create a fairly peaceful/naturalistic one with high living standards too. Base building ties in pretty well, there's a good gameplay loop of running a dungeon, then spending 1-2 days afterwards tending to your base and maybe exploring a bit. Dungeons are short & last approx. 6 - 12 minutes, though Isaac fans may lament the lack of sick combat metal. 

There's a lot to go over, so let's get to it.

General:

-Very cute aesthetic, Lamb especially so. Game's like a mini Binding of Isaac, but not nearly as gross. Varying levels of disturbing/uncanny stuff that you can lean into or out of

-Base building is fairly simple. I'm not always great with artsy construction, but even then I was able to create some pretty eye-catching stuff. Could use some QOL though, like being able to move building tiles before they're fully built & not having to re-enter the base building menu constantly. Additionally, I found the wood & stone buildings break way too quickly for my liking, and the main shrine could use more devotion cap. Late game it was being filled every 30s or so

-Stability started noticeably dipping during NG+, and got to the point of crashing/softlocking every 3rd or 4th dungeon run. Same goes for audio bugs. Notable examples include a repeating "hit" sound after summoning skeletons during a boss fight (persisting all the way to the main menu screen), cultists constantly talking during animations, and getting locked in a dungeon room after defeating a possessed cultist

-Lots of animations but only some can be skipped, frankly they ALL need an option to be skipped/sped up. Beyond annoyances of seeing the same things over and over again, some events later into the game are time sensitive. It's quite infuriating being stuck in a long "cultist levelling up" animation while you can hear two others trying to kill each other off-screen

-Regarding the alternate Don't Starve game mode that introduces hunger and sleep requirements: I liked the general sense of urgency it introduced & played my second full run on this mode, but I would have liked the ability to refill the meters mid-dungeon. Like if you killed the boss and had the option to refill both as a loot option. As it stands it basically constrains you to a single dungeon run, which is a problem for NG+'s "Purgatory" mode. Having to full clear 7 dungeons in a row with no refills or escape options is a bit too much to ask for a permadeath feature

-Rituals hit a good balance between accessibility and affordability. Food & mushroom-related ones are very powerful
 
Combat & Upgrades:

-Major point: not all weapons are created equal. I don't just mean that in a "different styles for different folks" sense, I mean some are just straight up bad. 
‚ÄÇ‚ÄÇ‚ÄÇ‚ÄÇ‚ÄÇ‚ÄÇThe dagger has way too low damage & range, the hammer & it's alt fire mode are kinda too slow (really needed to be a quicker, smaller alternate attack instead --- devs if you're listening, I will buy all this game's DLC, no questions asked, for the ability to G-Maul spec with the hammer. Make it happen)
‚ÄÇ‚ÄÇ‚ÄÇ‚ÄÇ‚ÄÇ‚ÄÇThe claws are fast & have the best AOE damage in the game, while the axe has probably the best DPS & a very powerful thrown alternate attack that takes skill & positioning to use properly 
‚ÄÇ‚ÄÇ‚ÄÇ‚ÄÇ‚ÄÇ‚ÄÇThe new blunderbuss gun is sorta meh early on, but gets way better once upgraded. The bane/poisoned version is by far the best weapon in the game, no questions asked
‚ÄÇ‚ÄÇ‚ÄÇ‚ÄÇ‚ÄÇ‚ÄÇThe sword I think might be bugged, I legitimately can't remember the last time I saw one in over 40 hours of play

-Dodging is... the only potential shade I'll throw regarding game design. Weapons drag you in the direction they're swinging in, leading to movement loss that actively fights against your intentions. This is the reason why the dagger's in a bad spot. Moreso, you don't roll in the direction your pressing the direction keys/controller in, you dodge in the current direction you're facing. There's no buffer input for this either, so if you're in the middle of a chaotic fight and roll to early, it's often deeper into danger instead of away from it. The implications of this on gameplay are very frustrating, to say the least

-Regarding weapon, curse & tarot upgrades, weirdly enough I actually found most of the later ones detrimental overall. For weapons, bane (and to a lesser degree vamperic) ones are worth using, but everything else before godly seemed too niche/inconsistent for my liking. Curses too; ichors, freezing and invulnerability ones are great, everything else is passable/situational. Most of the good tarot cards are also unlocked immediately, most of the purchasable ones not worth using and contaminate the drop pool. Example: damaging enemies when hit doesn't quite have the same value as doing increased weapon damage, or having more health

-Relics are mostly balanced, being able to recharge them by destroying environmental objects is a nice feature. All 3 lightning relics are still very strong

-Overall, I found dungeon runs to be very momentum-based. Combine all above points together; if you're tired/hungry/angry IRL, you can still probably have a good run if you're given proper weapons/resources. But you can easily lose a dagger or hammer run even if you're in peak mental condition

Regarding Sins of the Flesh Content:

-Drinking wine and being naked will turn you into a frothing demon that needs to be violently exorcized. Who knew. This is the kind of s**t hardcore Evangelists think will happen when they say you'll go to hell for touching yourself too much

-Anyway, Sin is the new mechanic that lets you beautify your temple, and also lets you monster mash your cultists together to produce customized hellspawn. If you've ever said to yourself "I don't have enough golden feces to properly fertilize my drug fields", this is the update for you. Jokes aside, it is nice being able to create tailored cultists who level up quickly with proper attention. With Skull necklaces they're functionally immortal. Sadly though, you can't breed the Lamb

-Too much Sin can make cultists turn into demons and fight against you in the next dungeon. This used to kill them when the update was first released, and created an interesting dynamic where it was optimal to "sacrifice" new/useless members as Sin generators. But I think people complained about it, so now they can be re-recruited after you've knocked them around a bunch, which I'm honestly not too keen on as there's now zero consequence for abusing this

-Tailoring is neat, but expensive. Again I'm not very creative with this, I only ever mass-produced outfits with resources that I wasn't using, and gave them to people I knew I was going to keep. Your mileage may vary. Also the tailor NPC runs out of stock WAY too fast and quickly becomes a useless room/encounter, would be nice if they sold crafting supplies after you've bought all their designs

-Final point; the new content comes VERY late into a main campaign run, like ¬æ of the way through. So if you aren't planning on doing the NG+ run afterwards, you'll realistically only have a single dungeon left to experience the new stuff

Overall a pretty great game, despite some gripes with weapons/spells/tarot stuff, and a few nagging QOL/stability issues. Main campaign run will probably last you 15-20 hours, pseudo NG+ a bit more than double that.

The updates this game has received since launch have fixed many of the issues that the base game had, With the recent update it now largely removes a need to grind as you should be able to finish any remaining upgrades before a run ends.

I do still think it's lacking in build variety, The Dungeon Fleece runs are a good addition but the game is still lacking in build customisation. Some relics/tarot cards can do things like increase your size, Improve attack rate, And add some abilities. But none really change your weapon's kit. I'm hoping we eventually see a content update that gives me a reason to finish the Dungeon mode, But as I've already finished several runs with all the weapons there's nothing new left to do with them.

A polished settlement simulator / top-down adventure game with an appealing aesthetic with quite a bit of dark humor throughout.

I think the game is well-made and worth the money for people who enjoy this kind of horror-esque macabre tone, but it's just not my taste.

--

I went back and did the post game. I'm now at 58 hours of playtime instead of just 8. I feel uncomfortable that it's required to permanently sacrifice followers to finish that portion, but I guess it's fair since you *will* get a replacement follower after you finish the zone. So I guess one can think of it as offering a new body to replace later.

Overall, I think the game is really good, but it *is* kind of a horror game and has quite a number of uncomfortable moments, no matter how hard you try to play it as a friendly cute and trustworthy lamb.

And no, you can't bang your favorite disciple. The lamb will be forever the last. (You can hook up your favorites with the other characters though.)

I don't know how intentional it is, but a lot of the cult-specific elements of the game do feel kinda like subtle social commentary. When I birthed my first new follower in-cult and saw how quickly the loyalty bar was going up, I nearly screamed. And then when I realized how fast loyalty goes up when taking care of them as a child I had the moment of "Wow, that's just like when I was a kid! Wait. WAIT. SHOULD I BE DOING THIS TO A KID, UHHHH THIS FEELS SLEEZYYYYY" and then next thing I know they've joined as a full time follower and already level XII, darn close to the max. In hardly a tenth of the time it took to get other characters to that level.

Also, if you get tired of the fishing/repair/cooking minigames, or if the battles start to drag on, go into the options and turn on all of the auto-fishing and change the difficulty and whatnot to whatever feels good. There is no penalty for it, you can genuinely just customize the game to be whatever is fun for you... except the cult stuff, the cult's gonna cult no matter what you want.

I'm not big on management, but this is about as bare-bones as it gets in that regard, which lets me have fun with it. Crusades (combat component) are very fun. You can be about as sadistic as you want to be with your cult members, or not sadistic at all. Tons of freedom there.

With everything in the base game plus Sins of the Flesh - a free, content-loaded expansion - my mind runs wild imagining the eventual (unannounced) sequel to this game. Cult has a ton of content but makes you want more in the best possible way. I seriously can't wait to see what's next, whether it's more free DLC, or even paid, or a sequel.

Be aware that currently I haven't found the depth for replayability in this game, however the base game is EXTREMELY worth it for the price. The gameplay, the vibes, the art are all great. The level of customization you have for your cultists is great, but also feeds into it's lack of replayability- cultists are just randomly generated and are either useful or not. It would be more fun to have some fixed characters with more mixed upside/downsides. Or just give us deeper village-building or something, IDK, it's a great core concept, but feels like the gameplay loop needs a little something more to keep people interested long term, which I think you can see from the playtimes on the reviews. Great game, just short- which was actually what I needed at the time I bought it. Even with buying the DLC, I only paid $2.25 per hour played so far.

Alright. Cult of the Lamb is done and dusted. This game is influenced by a lot of different games, but prominent amongst them are The Binding of Isaac and some Zeldas. The devs did a great job of adding their own spin to these while also including base building and follower management. It‚Äôs really got a little bit of a lot of genres. There‚Äôs even some lite bullet hell sequences based on enemy and boss abilities. And there are some mini games as well. :)

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3136751519

The story is pretty silly. A group of monster bishops go about the business of sacrificing all lambs in the world. You‚Äôre the last lamb, but when they sacrifice you, an evil god intervenes, making you his avatar in the world. Your goal is to found and build up a cult to his worship while building up your cult‚Äôs base to feed and shelter your cultists, gather their worship energy, and generally build both your power and the power of your cultists. You will use your cult‚Äôs base as the launching point for various quests including your other primary goal: to kill the bishops that have imprisoned your god.

The base building is not disimilar from various RTS games. You‚Äôll build a variety of buildings that will accomodate your religion and your cultists. You‚Äôll also farm, mine, cut lumber, cook food, gather that worship energy I mentioned earlier. You‚Äôll (unfortunately) also clean up your cultist‚Äôs poop, which they‚Äôll drop indiscriminately around your base until you finally build some outhouses, and even then, they‚Äôll let it go sometimes. Freaking animals! You‚Äôll also also build a prison to discourage dissent amongst your followers, crypts for the dead, etc..

Your cultists can and will die despite never leaving your compound outside of some story moments when they‚Äôre summoned elsewhere. Some will grow old and die of old age. You‚Äôll sacrifice others. Depending on circumstances, cultists can also murder each other. However, they also develop relationships amongst themselves and with you, and maintaining your relationship with your cultists is of paramount importance.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3136751070

Then there are the dungeons. These are presented in Binding of Isaac fashion. However, this isn‚Äôt a twin stick shooter. Instead, it‚Äôs melee and magic focused, where you‚Äôll use weapons, relics, and sometimes actual spells to fight your way through each dungeon. However, it strays from Isaac by also including node maps between dungeons that might also include new followers, supplies, extra battles, etc‚Ä¶The Zelda mechanics show themselves in the actual combat. Plus, there is a heart health system which is used in both of CotL‚Äôs main influences.

The node system will eventually lead to the area boss, who you will defeat and then recruit. In each bishop‚Äôs area, you‚Äôll need to complete them four times. The fourth time, it unlocks the bishop battle.

The world also features other locations where you‚Äôll meet allies and complete quests and such. Which leads me to the RPG mechanics. You will have several categories of unlocks, from weapons and relics to rituals (which you‚Äôll use for buffs, resurrecting dead cultists, and so on), new buildings and decorations, etc‚Ä¶there are a lot of upgrades and many tiers to some of them.

So yeah. There‚Äôs a lot to Cult of the Lamb, and I‚Äôm really just scratching the surface of what is available in the game. Once you finish the game, you can keep playing, wrapping up cheevos and doing some extra story stuff if you‚Äôre so inclined. You also unlock some difficulty modes.

The graphics and audio are all geared towards emphasizing the cutesy and yet murdery nature of the world. It‚Äôs a very pleasing game mixed with pleasing horror, lol. And the soundtrack was really cool as well.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3136751294

I will also note that despite the various gameplay mechanics, the game does a great job of teaching you how to play in a very approachable and intuitive manner.

It took me right around 13 hours to play through the campaign, but I think you could easily get another 10ish hours trying to wrap up cheevos. I played on the Steam Deck on the highest settings with no issues and about 2 hour battery life.

Cost vs value is definitely there with this one. The devs do recommend using a gamepad, so if you‚Äôre strictly k/m, you might want to look more into it before buying, but it‚Äôs an easy recommendation and one of the best Indies out there.

[h1]A Darkly Whimsical Masterpiece Awaits![/h1]

Cult of the Lamb beckons players into an enchanting yet sinister realm where the unexpected thrives. As the leader of a burgeoning cult, you'll guide your endearing lamb protagonist through a blend of management, strategy, and dungeon exploration.

Visually, the game is a treat, with its captivating art style breathing life into its quirky inhabitants and haunting locales. Every aspect, from the intricately designed cult structures to the diverse cast of characters, oozes charm and personality.

The gameplay mechanics strike a delicate balance between accessibility and depth, offering a satisfying mix of strategic decision-making and fast-paced action. From managing resources to engaging in thrilling dungeon battles, every choice feels meaningful and impactful.

What truly sets Cult of the Lamb apart is its narrative depth and world-building. As you uncover the secrets of the game's universe and interact with its eccentric characters, you'll find yourself drawn deeper into its darkly enchanting lore.

While the game's difficulty curve may pose a challenge for some players, it only serves to enhance the sense of accomplishment upon overcoming obstacles. With each victory and setback, you'll forge a unique path through the twisted landscape of Cult of the Lamb.

In conclusion, Cult of the Lamb is a shining example of indie gaming innovation, offering an unforgettable experience that lingers long after the credits roll. Whether you're drawn to its whimsical charm or its darker undertones, prepare to be captivated by the magic that awaits within its unsettling embrace.

Absolutely the most fun and adorable action/community management game I've played so far. The amount of content is amazing, from follower forms, to buildings/decorations, to abilities, even the combat has a wealth of content attached with weapons/curses/relics/strategy involved based on the items you have.

I MUST praise the music and visual aspects as well, which add to the "cult" vibe. The music is AMAZING, and the menu music is especially lovely to me with how hauntingly BEAUTIFUL it is. The visual aspects are superb as well. A cutesy/cartoony look coupled with creepy level/enemy design, not to mention the designs of the bosses/mini-bosses, all absolutely awesome and fun to admire. 

I highly recommend this game for sure, if you can handle the heavy occult symbolism and philosophy the game has, and some mild graphic content. (Mild graphic content compared to some other games I've played.)

Fun rogue-lite with base building and management to make yourself stronger. Lots to unlock and different play styles to keep things interesting for a while. Dialogue, gameplay and story are all interesting and funny enough to keep you playing until the end. I still put in hours after the ending as the game was throwing new things into the mix. Developers are also adding free updates that add new content, so will probably return as new updates continue to appear for the game.

I'm gonna rate this game positive, since it hooked me for 10 hours straight, but the longer you play, the more evident the flaws become. At first, it's exciting and fun managing a cult, but as you progress, it quickly becomes repetitive doing the same daily tasks for the cult: cleaning, cooking, performing a sermon, and ritual. This basically needs to be done after EVERY dungeon run, and takes a considerable amount  of time. There are plenty of things to unlock, but these are basically upgraded versions of previous buildings that grant some minor bonus effects. My biggest gripe with this game is the combat. Not once have I had a run where I felt like I was progressively getting stronger, to really encompass that ACTION ROGUELIKE feeling. The upgrade systems are so bland and boring, and never change the actual mechanics of the combat. Basically just boring passive effects, with some rehashed abilities. Its the same gameplay loop, and doesn't suck you back in for another run. The art style is great though. Glad I got this game on sale, because once I finished it, I really have no motivation to play through a dungeon again.

I'm sure this is a great game, I know it is I've seen gameplay of it. But it simply will not play for me. there's weird graphical issues with red, all throughout the intro sequence, and when it gets to the point where the one who waits gives you the crown, whatever cutscene is supposed to play just doesn't have any visuals. I can still hear it, but there's nothing but a black screen and a skip prompt. The skip prompt also doesn't work, and it just sits on a black screen indefinitely. This makes the game unplayable for me. I've tried resetting my computer, updating my graphics drivers, reinstalling the game. I'm tired of playing through the intro cutscene over and over again. So while the game is good I can't exactly make a recommendation on something I can't play. I've requested a refund.

Edit: apparently this black screen bug is a pretty well documented issue and has been for years.
Edit 2: I'm fortunate enough to be in the same house with someone who also owns this game, so I was able to test if the patch they put out today fixed my issue and it did. I'm still going to leave my review up the way it is just until I can get the game for myself again and leave a proper review. But this is a good game, so as long as you go into it going you may have issues getting it to work give it a go.

Picture this: you're this cute, customizable lamb navigating through these annoying dungeons. What's cool is how the gameplay strikes this sweet balance between action and strategy. As you guide your satanist lamb through challenges, you unlock new abilities and gain adepts, adding this extra layer of fun and depth to the game.

This is really hard not to love. You have to go out of your way not to have a good time. Although there are flaws just under the surface, every bit of this game goes out of its way to make you have a good time.

Firstly, this game is a joy for your ADHD addled brain. I cannot exaggerate how much STUFF is going on. The gameplay loop is so fast. There's always something happening and there's always something to do; it's like Stardew Valley on steroids. The difference here is, by nature of the passage of time - and that passage of time being relatively short - your time is valuable. What you do, when you do it, and how you do it, and in what order, can really make a difference if you love optimization. And because all the tasks are different - from dungeon crawling, to town management, to villager decorations, to fishing - none of the gamplay loops outstay their welcome. You're bouncing between 9 different tasks, and because all of the tasks are different, you never really get bored.

Which is where the actual problem in this game lies: it's deceptively shallow. It feels like there's a lot going on here. But in reality, everything is based on timers. With the exception of dungeon crawling, and some side mini-games like fishing, and the mini-game knucklebones (otherwise known as addictive), most of the actual management tasks are really superficial and simple. Regarding attention again, they definitely hold your attention. But only just. 

Cult of the Lamb uses lots of dopaminergic responses to make you feel good, more than any other game I've ever played. Everything is in a constant state of making you feel good, from the animations, to the art, to the satisfaction of the combat, all the way down to making your villagers happy. It's designed, top to bottom, to make your dopamine swim. The issue is, it's almost rude in a way; it's almost like the game is tricking you into believing that waiting-mechanics are fun. It's very good at doing this. But at the heart of every mechanics, except for dungeon crawling, you'll be waiting. Waiting for a villager to complete a task, or the building to be built, or the thing to be completed. There's nothing inherently wrong with this. But there's a lot of it, and it's concealed under a giant layer of quaintness and cuteness. That is to say, if you played this game and bounced off of it, disliking it incredibly, you are super valid and there are a lot of reasons you might not like this game.

But I liked this game. It's addictive tendencies suit my tiny brain perfectly. The management systems, although they are not complex, are fun and rewarding. I basically maxed out my village before I even half-way completed the game, because I was so obsessed with making everything perfect that I overdid it, and hyper-optimized everything. The fact that the game continually rewards you for that, and also doesn't punish you if you don't optimize in the way that I did, is a testament to its own design.

And also, like, c'mon bro. This is fun. Play this game for 10-20 minutes, and you'll be smiling. Even if you don't like this, you can't knock it for being FUN. It's just cute, and neat, and silly, and sweet. And we need more nice things in this cold, cruel world of ours. Even if something isn't perfectly, sometimes something being pretty neat is all that's necessary.

I wish there was a way to give this game a 3/5. It was quite a fun game with an enjoyable, snappy combat loop, but the QoL for town management was rather poor and the total amount of content in the game is pretty low. While $25 is a reasonable price for a game, it only took me about 13 hours to reach the end and I don't really feel compelled to keep playing for achievements.

Pros:
- Aesthetic is great. Really amusing plot and the don't-starve-like graphics reinforce the vibe.
- Combat is fun and responsive. 
- Decent balance of mechanics to learn without being overwhelming and good pacing

Cons:
- Very poor colony management QoL features
- Infuriatingly slow, unskippable animations throughout (especially annoying is the new blueprint pickup)
- Passage of time during combat runs makes everything feel rushed
- Resource acquisition and management was tedious
- Lack of variety and choice in combat loadouts - you basically just pick random weapons and roll with it
- Upgrade paths are mostly irrelevant

I think in general, the main thing I didn't like about this game was that it both encouraged you to explore dungeons and break everything in them for loot, but also your colony gets messed up while you're away and the longer you're away the worse it is. So there's this competing interest that resulted in me basically speed-running the combat portions just so I could get back to my cult sooner.

So, while the combat and premise were good, there were a lot of small complaints about the game. Still worth a play (if a short one).

Cult of the Lamb is a good game that has only become better with its major updates Relics of the old faith (ROTOF) and Sins of the Flesh (SOTF), both of which are totally free and come with the base game. Previously I would have only Recommended it on sale, but now I think it‚Äôs well worth its Full price. But if you take anything else from this review let it be at least be these 3 funny cult names:

The Graveyardigans

Flowerpach Kin

Happy Tree Fiends

To start, Cult of the lamb‚Äôs central gimmick is that it is split between two different game loops: Cult Management and Crusades. Which are Base-Building and Rougelike respectively, you cannot play entirely one or the other or you will not be able to make any meaningful progress. This is a down-point for people who are fans purely of one genre or another, base-builders don't like grindy dungeon crawling, rouge-fans don‚Äôt like babysitting the followers back at base. These are Both valid personal points to take, as each side of the game is verifiably diminished by the other existing. But it is as combined does CotL‚Äôs appeal lie.
Together, each side of the game gives special context to the other, you are encouraged to go through dungeons as quickly and effectively as possible, as time in your base does not stop when fighting. Building up your cult as well and giving your followers attention and time can give you unique advantages in crusades, giving a significant Powerup at the beginning. Both are a Yin and Yang you must engage with to get a full experience.
Being a fan of both genres, like me, will also greatly increase the enjoyment of CotL but is not essential I think as an appeal to enjoy it

It rocks a cute cartoon aesthetic that is infused into everything as well. From the beloved followers, to grimy eldritch titans and all that falls between, accompanied by a mid-sized cast of unique characters, who really need more ways and reasons to be talked with as interactions with them are very limited. Alongside much of other side content outside of the main two game-modes which I feel needs to be expanded greatly and holds it back from being a fantastic game. The Irregular updates the game receives have also something to consider if buying, as they will be continuing into the foreseeable future.
Felt as a whole that CotL was a good experience for me and that it fit snugly within my gaming preferences and aesthetics. It's a nice recommendation from me.

Cult of the Lamb seamlessly blends elements from Hades, Binding of Isaac, Enter the Gungeon, and Stardew Valley to deliver a uniquely addictive gaming experience. The fast-paced combat, reminiscent of Hades and Gungeon, keeps each run thrilling, while Isaac's influence shines in dungeon-crawling and quirky enemies.

The unexpected farming aspect, inspired by Stardew Valley, adds a serene touch between dungeon runs, offering a delightful break from the chaos. Though the base game has four dungeon types with limited enemy variety, the addictive gameplay compensates, encouraging replayability and strategic exploration.

Noteworthy is the developer's commitment, evident through consistent updates and new content. Cult of the Lamb is a captivating blend of roguelike intensity, farming charm, and dedicated developers, making it a must-play for indie game enthusiasts. Dive in, explore dungeons, cultivate your farm, and brace yourself for an experience that easily surpasses 20 hours ‚Äì and more if you're chasing that 100 percent completion.

Cult of the Lamb is a nice experience overall, even if there are a few quirks. Many people make comparisons to other games being mixed together, which is definitely appropriate - this game is about the sum of its parts, and the parts have some good inspirations. Hades, Moonlighter, Don't Starve, Animal Crossing, 2D Zelda games, and The Binding of Isaac are all apt comparisons.

The two main gameplay loops are tending to your cult and going on crusades. While caring for your flock, you'll be managing resources to keep everyone happy, healthy, fed, and complacent to your demands. While crusading, you'll be destroying your competition in combat to gather more resources.

The game does a nice job drip feeding you new unlocks and mechanics. There are whole subsystems that open up to you after a while, so stick with it even when it seems tedious. There are lots of ways to automate features the further you get into the game. The base building is satisfying, and seeing the cultists do their work is quite funny. 

Humor is interwoven throughout the game, even when it's trying to be imposing. If you enjoy macabre humor about religion and cults, you'll find this game amusing.

There are some minor issues that I have with the game, such as trying to select one individual cultist to talk to later in the game and struggling to get them to highlight (likely wouldn't be as much of an issue if I play with KB+M) but overall I had a lovely time and chewed through my playthrough in a handful of days. It sucked me in!

Have your expectations low before playing this game, don't even bother worrying 
about your Village and Followers. You just stockpile them to Indoctrinate later when 
you can fight the game's Final Boss. You can easily beat Cult of the Lamb with bare 
minimum upgrades playing in Normal mode, you can ignore using the Temple entirely. Sermons, Rituals, Doctrines are not required to beat the game. The Rouge like and 
Village Builder genres together could work, but the execution is mediocre at best.
If your more into action heavy Rogue-like games just simply skip Cult of the Lamb 
and forget about it. If you like casual games like Animal Crossing, go ahead you'll 
have a better experience playing it. Lacks replay ability but its fun to finish once.

Hello and welcome to one - if not THE - most stressful roguelike on the market.

Did you ever want to scream at your screen asking for the 69th time WHY OH WHY DOES EVERYONE IN NEED OF TAKING A DUMP OR VOMITING HAVE TO WALK AT THE EDGE OF THE MAP TO MAKE IT EVEN MORE ANNOYING FOR YOU TO CLEAN IT UP?

Or do you like to see your followers eat each other to bits and pieces, sacrifice them to a monster or bind them to torture devices to make them obedient - but when they see the corpse of someone who died of old age, they are going to freak out and immediately VOMIT EVERYWHERE? Even better, Jeff 55 days died of old age, and Marcus came from his work 100 meters away just to visit the corpse only to fucking puke. It's like Marcus thought "Hmm, I could vomit right now, but I dunno, I'm not keen on eating something rotten.. oh hey, is that a corpse over there? Let's FUCKING GOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOO!". BRUH I EVEN TRIED TO MOVE THE CORPSE AT THE EDGE OF THE MAP AND YET VOMIT LIES WHERE THE CORPSE SHOULD HAVE FUCKING RESTED INSTEAD.

Do you like when you recruit mature grown-ups only to realize that when they get sick, not only won't they do any work, they instead run around the map aimlessly until you explicitly tell them to go fuck themselves in the healing tent or go to bed until they get better?

How about your followers admiring and worshipping you as a literal god, only to act like a puppy who enjoys looking at you in the eyes while you have to clean up the shit they dump all over the map, because YOU have somehow a fucking broom but they refuse to take care of their own shit. You like that, don't ya?

Or the fact that you have to run through dungeons stressful and in a hurry, since the time in the dungeon reflects the time outside and if your fucking followers are left alone for a whole day, they start to get awfully hungwry and all angsty as they shit the fucking bed and of course can't feed themselves or clean up after themselves, resulting in sickness and lovely non-stressful messages during your runs like "HEY YOUR FOLLOWER IS SICK NOW AND WILL DIE IF LEFT UNTREATED". 

This is one of the reasons why I fucking scratched my head why oh why you unlock endless dungeon runs so early. You can't leave em alone without your followers dying or worse revolting.
However... after a while you unlock the technology tree as you learn how to automate wiping your followers butts, building a fucking shed with a broom so they can use to clean up their own projectile vomit and even a second kitchen that followers can use, because the first one has a bomb implanted that would result in killing everyone and everything in a 5000 mile (are we still using retarded unit measurements? What's that in even more retarded units? 300 football fields?) radius as a follower touches the kitchen. With that, you finally start to go through dungeons less stressed and you can go for longer.

You also learn ways of capitalism by making your followers admit going on a dietary restriction of eating air while still working at 100% capacity for couple days, coupled with abilities of free speech aka modern free speech where everything they say is forbidden as it is non-compliant with a healthy work relationship, meaning they have to endure it without losing faith in you as the god. Oh and of course non-paid overwork as they won't have to sleep too now. And don't forget to introduce a tax for just existing, that will keep production up even higher Ah yes, the modern free world.

So yeah, I recommend this game.
I bought this game under a week ago. I have a full time 8hr work day, 5 days a week, and somehow I've already put almost a day of playing in. help

Cult of the lamb is phenomenal, an incredible indie effort that is packed with charm and dark humour, an incredible blend of slice of life sim and a dungeon crawling rouge like, a game with a massive amount of complexity hidden under a simple shell with plenty of unlockables, skill trees, cosmetics and mini games. 

Presented with a cutesy 2d style, cult of the lamb is intriguing from the get go and doesn't waste time pulling you into the cult life, you will soon amass plenty of followers to do your bidding, be it working in the quarry, eating poop or sacrificing them to the elder gods. For me this was the strongest aspect of the game, your followers are flexible and the level of interaction is really impressive. Had a favourite follower die? Fret not, just use some arcane knowledge to resurrect them and if the extensional dread of being pulled back from the afterlife is too much and they start to lose faith, kill them and serve them up for dinner. 

Combat and dungeon crawling is the other big game mode and it's the weakest part though that's not to say it's bad because it really isn't, it's deep enough to be engaging but simple enough that you don't need to worry about balancing builds. You have attacks, heavy attacks, spells, passive buffs and summons but it never feels too overwhelming, might be a drawback for some but doesn't bother me, you are always rewarded with something for your efforts and generally Combat is fun if a little samey by the end. There isn't too much incentive for re-running completed areas for now but it seems a free update will be focused on endgame content. 

The devs have been amazing with this games support, we've just had a massive free update which adds seggs and they are going to bring a significant update to endgame, all while selling completely optional cosmetic dlc which thankfully doesn't impact gameplay. 

Simply one of the best indies in recent memory, an absolute joy to play and I hope it's a game that gets plenty of support (already has to be fair) in it's life. I have been fully indoctrinated into the cult and it's time for you to convert.

Heavy on style, low on substance. It was pleasant enough to keep me along for the ride, but it never did anything terribly impressive and I was glad when it was over.

My biggest gripe is the disregard for Quality of Life features. Equipping a follower is done by hunting them down and interacting with them, instead of a simple menu. Summons need to be refreshed after every crusade for no particular reason. Unskippable animations every time you unlock another minor aesthetic upgrade (which happens frequently.)

Lots of pointless busywork. You need to tell followers to sleep when they're sick or tired or they'll just work until they die. Why?? What is the point of this time-wasting mechanic?

The combat is ok. It could use a lot more visual clariy, as enemies tend to blend into the environment and their attack cues get lost in the sauce. It doesn't develop much over time either.

Only buy this if you'll get a lot of pleasure out of customizing the appearance of your followers and base.

I wish Steam allowed more options than good or bad. I'd rather leave this game 4 out of 5 stars if I could. The game is fun, and the combat is great. The colony management was awesome at first, but it gets boring and somewhat annoying after completing upgrade trees. The game started going downhill as soon as I maxed out my doctrines (not including sin). Managing the colony started to feel pointless after I maxed out the combat benefits tree.

I appreciate that at many times I was given options to choose good or evil directions, but I hated that the Sin mechanic doesn't seem to allow much choice. Even if I used the non-violent options to generate sin it still ended up harming my followers. Overall I don't feel that the sin update added anything enjoyable to the game. I would rather see more doctrines allowing the colony to manage itself, ways to build more meaningful relationships with followers, and more combat related challenges and upgrades.

Overall I enjoyed Hades more than this game, but I would still recommend Cult of the Lamb to friends if they've played Hades already. I had a few good laughs and the combat in this game is exciting.

Cult of the Lamb is an enjoyable rouge-like dungeon crawler mixed with a simplistic base-building game, filled with dark humor and cute little animal critters. The dungeon crawling is challenging without being too difficult, providing the right balance between fun and frantic, just as running your cult requires a little strategy, but not too much to distract you from the rest of the game. 

What complaints I do have about the game are minor: mostly that I think your cultists grow old and die a little too quickly, I wish the building map was a little bigger, and I find that the diagonal grid you build on can sometimes be a little finicky when placing small 1-tile objects.

Overall, this game is fantastic and is worth the buy even at full price.

Fun at the start, but overstays it's welcome. The enjoyment from managing followers quickly wears off and feels like it just slows everything down. By the final dungeon I had enabled the option to pause time while on a crusade to avoid follower management. The dungeons themselves feel repetitive and the build depth and options you have in the rogue lite aspect is very shallow.

The whole roguelite build system could really be expanded, it's all on the tarot cards, but unlocking new tarot cards actually feels like a negative as you are just watering down the pool lowering your chances at the good ones. The relics all feel too similar especially with all the damned and blessed versions.

The devs have done a massive amount of post launch support, but rather than adding new systems and extending the grind maybe they could flesh out what is already there.

The postgame and sin grind isn't something I even want to try engage with. It's great that there's options to skip all the pointless things like crafting, cooking and fishing. But still feels like it could really do with more quality of life options like skipping the same animations that repeat (travelling, sermons, doctrines, rituals) having all the resources collected go to one place, infinite ways to harvest wood and stone, extended resource conversion to the higher tiers, followers going to bed when they are sick without you having to tell them.

The last boss is pretty difficult (in a good way) especially since you have random weapons and spells, so it was really frustrating their was no easy way to retry and you had to go through the walk and cut scenes again every time, though sometimes I could skip the first cut scene and sometimes I couldn't.

On technical side the game is fairly polished, I experienced one crash early on from sitting in the church screen too long. But received multiple crashes on the last boss and going to and starting the post game. Bug wise, had some issues where I would be put into cut scenes but still take damage from the hazard I was standing on. Also not sure if it was a bug or something I missed, but sometimes half my followers would just get sick from performing rituals (not the mushroom ritual with the prohibitionist trait) had it happen from alms to the poor, ascension and sacrifice.

The most frustrating bug I had though was after the 4th boss the game would just vibrate the controller and ignore inputs at random intervals when in a dungeon. I know it was caused by this game as it didn't happen in the steam controller test or when in other games that I opened at the same time to test it. In the end I just had to switch to mouse and keyboard.

It's a fun game for those who like to build and manage NPC-s and also for those who like combat.
The concept is funny, and a bit satirical, but overall very enjoyable. Also I have to add, that this game is probably better with controllers instead of keyboard :) 
The graphics are creepy and cute at the same time. I love the adorable designs of the Lamb and the NPCs, however it can pretty quickly turn into some kind of eldritch horror too.

Cult of the Lamb is a roguelite dungeon crawling game that also has a colony management mixed into it. And the gameplay loop surprisingly works so well. You build you cult from the ground up, gather resources or gain new follower by going into the "dungeons", where the roguelite aspect comes in. Depends on your skill level, average runtime per dungeon run is 6 to 8 minutes. And then you go back to your cult base camp with your resources / new follower, do some colony management sim thingy, and then off to do another "dungeon" run again. 

Combat is pretty simple, although some of the weapon hitbox is kinda jank (the axe comes to mind), and on some boss fight, it gets so hectic that there's so many particles cluttering the arena. Beyond that, the gameplay is pretty solid. 
There's 3 choice in difficulty, so if you prefer a relaxed experience, you can do that, and if that is not enough, there's also accessibility option if you still feel the game is kinda hard.

Best of all, they actually added sex into the game, as per other players request. What a mad lad. 
I highly recommend this game to any roguelite fans alike

But making a cap at level 10 is a bit... low? A big core part of the game is gaining loyalty of your followers. Removing the heart demon's effects from the fragile and beserker fleece was fair. I genuinely feel like there was a better way to nerf the followers versus removing the ability to level them up completely.

I really don't care if there's a demon level cap or if there's a devotion cap for sacrifices or anything else, but I'm an idiot who likes to grind levels.

Overall, love the game, update is fire (minus the fact I can't sex Narinder)

I saw the credits which I consider an ending, although there is a significant amount of post game. I also played on the recommended difficulty, 

This is a very cute game, that's very thoughtfully built. The mechanics of roguelike and town builder blend nicely and the time given for runs before things fall apart feels just about right to be manageable, with extra options to extend your time out if needed. I think the very beginning of the game it's a pain to get established, but after a few necessary resource runs it picks up a lot more. 

I think the follower mechanics are interesting and both the aging mechanic and random element make it difficult to keep your whole flock alive, it encourages you to accept the inevitability of members you like dying, and even encourages you to do it yourself. 

The combat is simple but just mechanically varied enough to be satisfying, mostly relying on your movement around enemy attacks and remembering patterns and exploiting weaknesses. Some weapon types seem infinitely better than others so it can feel like a massive die roll for how good the first area of the run will be, but after you have some good curses and relics that starts to matter less. 

The visuals and audio carry a lot of the game for me. The rarewarespeak and music are both very charming, and the characters are very cute. I like how much control you have over individual followers looks, and the NPCs are all memorable. I don't feel like the core game has a whole lot of story to attach yourself to, [spoiler]but most of it seems to be locked behind post game. [/spoiler]

It can get a bit repetitive and you can get locked into a loop of meaningless follower tasks if you allow yourself to, but I think this game has a tight enough game loop to come back to, and is simple enough that I could check in a year from now and still be able to play and enjoy it.

So far, I am on my first play through and have done all doctrines and am pushing the 4th bishop currently. The game feels like there's an endless amount of things to do/manage (in a good way)! You're never left idling and wondering, "what should I do right now?"

This game is like the cuteness and coziness of Stardew Valley meets a Hades-esque progression system, with a dungeon roguelike element of a more polished Binding of Isaac.

The graphics are gorgeous and easy to look at, the music pairs well with the experience, and the game has phenomenal sound design. 

For the price they sell it at, it's almost a mistake to NOT buy it - fantastic game that I'm glad I've purchased. Plus, the new Sins of the Flesh update was entirely free and added a ton of new, fun content to the game.

The cult mechanic is super fun to also work on, making a cult that is horrible in every aspect, to making a cult thats loving for one another, its all up to you. This game is super fun if youre into building and caring for your followers, and fighting bosses and unlocking sweet new weapons.

Getting 100% was... enjoyable in this cutely disturbing cult simulator.

approximate amount of time to 100%: 20-40
Estimated achievement difficulty: 4/10
Minimum number of playthroughs needed: One + DLC (a sort of NG+)
Multiplayer achievements: No.
Missable achievements: Yes. A single super easy one. (play dice with Rattau and win once you can and you can continue easily)
Grinding Achievements: No.
DLC-Only achievements: No. (but new achievements were added with updates)
Time-gated achievements: No.
Speed-run achievements: No.
RNG-achievements: A few. (some collectibles can spawn in rooms at random)
Does difficulty affect achievements: No. You can get 100% on easy.
First achievement unlock: Almost immediately at the start of the game. (sign the contract/Recruit a cultist)

Notes: 
- The game features negative achievements (like dying, sacrificing followers) achievements depend on these.
- The last 10~ hours were spent grinding the final item from cards/follower skins/relics etc..
- QOL Mods don't block achievements (like lock weapons or auto gather from chests...)
   (somewhat spoilery)
- the npc that sells "the Intangible" card is only found ONLY in Anchordeep [ The guides lie, he doesn't spawn everywhere ] - My advice is to keep 200~gold on hand and always buy all the card unlocks that are offered in random dungeon events.
- Make sure to chose the "resurrection" dogma.  With the free update you can select the dogmas you missed but that's very late into the game.

Overall the game was fun, It kept things varied between combat and base building just enough to prevent either from becoming stale. I personally love the art style and the only thing I found lacking were quality of life features (some of which can be easily modded in)

Overall this gets a strong recommendation from me. Go do unspeakable things to your followers

Edit: 6 New achievements were added as part of the free "Sins of the Flesh" DLC addition.
- Most of the new achievements simply reward getting to the end of a gameplay feature, (like making eggs/disciples etc...)
- The Lore and Costume ones however are a different story..  Wasted tens of hours on just the Grindy RNG of trying to get that damned Meat room for the final one.

Cult of The Lamb is legitimately one of the best games I've ever played
POSITIVES:
‚Ä¢ Large selection of fleeces makes combat interesting, and let's you tailor it to your preferences
‚Ä¢ Cult building is actually super fun, I tend not to enjoy more passive stuff, but cult building is my favourite part of the game
‚Ä¢ Absolutely fucking gorgeous game, super stylized and cute while still being genuinely unsettling at times
‚Ä¢ Plenty of fun characters that make you wonder about the rest of the world outside of the few areas you can visit.
‚Ä¢ A metric fuck ton of enemies that are all pretty distinct, and you have to play around them differently
‚Ä¢ GOD HAVE YOU SEEN HOW PRETTY THIS GAME IS OH MY GOD
‚Ä¢ Did I mention how good it looks yet?

NEGATIVES:
‚Ä¢ Can get a bit grindy at times, I've had to spend 30-45 minutes just getting followers so I can open the next area.
‚Ä¢ You sometimes get screwed over with bad weapon luck. "oh you're using a glass cannon build? TAKE A HAMMER!!"
‚Ä¢ The game does depend on you doing about equal amounts of cult building and dungeon running. It'll break otherwise

There's probably a couple more positives and negatives I forgot to mention, but they're all pretty minimal.

After buying Cult of the Lamb about a year ago, I think it's time for a review. I liked it when I bought it, but something just didn't click with me. I like games with light management, dungeon crawling, and base building. But the game just wasn't there, yet.

With Sins of the Flesh, the free update, the game feels right. The management is coming together later in the game and I think there are even more necklaces and blueprints for me to find. The dungeon crawling feels better. Hits seem to land more accurately and the blunderbuss is a fun addition to the arsenal. The base building is expanded with the new sin mechanic letting followers be even more self-serving and beneficial.

Cult of the Lamb is certainly worth your time when on sale, but even at full price it's a fun, entertaining game. The combat isn't super deep, but it is rewarding. Collecting the right cards and finding a great setup feels good. Changing fleeces and discovering what works for you makes runs so enjoyable.

If you like managing villagers, though, Cult of the Lamb is a must-buy. You can collect them, get rid of them if you don't like their perks, breed them, dress them, and care for them. It wasn't quite there at release, but now the game is so much fun!

It is a fantastic game, the dungeon crawling is awesome, i love the way how you have to start by doing everything and then later on the followers can do it for you, the last boss fight was super fun aswell
Sex update.......

Not only is the combat for the dungeons insanely satisfying and endlessly entertaining with the amount of power-ups you can collect, but there's also a farming/building aesthetic packaged in as you slowly craft your little growing band of simps that worship you day and night. I appreciate the variety of going back and forth between harvesting materials/progressing through the storyline with combat and then returning to your little cult at the end of the day to take care of all your little animals. There's always something to do, it feels very fast-paced the majority of the time, never a dull moment.

The added Twitch-integration makes it even better (I played through this for my first run livestreaming), allowing your viewers to participate by "becoming" cult members, adding to your totem, and "deciding your fate" which is a vote to cause you hindrances or give you bonuses, can even resurrect dead members if they want to! Playing with viewers is exceptionally fun because there's so much *drama* that goes on in the cult and getting your audience involved with that is like telling a little story that keeps them coming back for every new episode. ;)

It's plain to see that the team behind this game has put a lot of love and thought into it. The recent new DLC has added a whole new charm to it as well, it brought me back for a second playthrough with my viewers on Twitch and together we are all having an absolute blast!

Editing Review to include Sins of the Flesh 1/19/24: 
This game is a solid 9.5/10 in my book.

I highly enjoy this DLC! It adds a fantastic amount of replayability with some grinding that is not excessive! Overall, i still absolutely LOVE this game.The art style, music, characters, and gameplay is overall just fantastic. The amount of value you get out of this game and the dedication of the team to continue to update the game with so much new content for free (with each expansion offering a very affordable bonus-DLC option) is absolutely amazing.

For context I've spent about 20 hours playing the update so far at the time of writing.
Pros:
- Sin offers new rewards and a new grind that is actually enjoyable
- Mating allows you to combine traits of your favorite Cultists, reject eggs can be broken for a new resource! They did a great job making the value of breaking your eggs balanced.
- New quest lines are enjoyable, especially the Sozo questline! (I have not yet finished the Lore one, but the fact that it has brought back a lot of value to running Crusades again makes me very happy)
- The Blunderbuss!! New weapon, fun times. If you were wishing that Cult of the Lamb had a ranged weapon, then you'll be thrilled! It has "ammunition" that takes time to regenerate after each shot (it takes longer to reload if it fully runs out). Adds some extra thought to combat and is a very refreshing edition for someone who will reset a run if he doesn't get the dagger. (me)
- They added new kinds of poop.
- New follower forms are hilarious and adorable
- New Traits! Some are great, some are negative, some devalue Devoation in exchange for boosting Sin and vice versa. Never a bad thing to add more variation and automatically adds so much value to the mating system.
- Outfits - You can put Leshy in a Maid Outfit....'nuff said.
- Several other Quality of Life improvements (please read the Patch Notes for all of them)
- New Doctrines and RItuals!! (read the patch notes)

There are so many more, but these are the most notable ones in my opinion!

Cons:
- Level for Followers caps at 10. This genuinely bums me out, it does not revert existing Followers to level 10, which is very nice, but it is disappointing that this was implemented as it deters me further from bringing followers on crusades with me. (I also really wanted to get a follower up to a ridiculous level) I feel like it was added to justify the new Disciple mechanic, but why drop the level cap?
- Sin is very cool, but be careful with it because you'll find yourself needing to resurrect your Followers quite often! (this is mostly a con when you first start trying to farm it and do not understand it)
- God Tears are still pretty underwhelming. I find that the only thing that I want from farming them is the Gold Skull Necklace to prevent followers from dying of old age. I have probably 70 necklaces I just don't use and nothing to really do with them if I don't use them. After receiving all of the follower forms, cosmetics, and Forgotten Doctrine, it just feels like I'm gambling for the necklace I want.
- Purgatory: The above opinion sorta plays into Purgatory, aside from the Achievement, Purgatory does not seem to offer more than a self-fulfilling challenge that lays there at a relative completeness depending on the value you place on challenge runs. Maybe that was the intent? Regardless, I haven't really touched Purgatory since getting the Achievement for it.

(God Tears and Purgatory were introduced in the previous Expansion, Relics of the Old Faith, I did not think to update my review for that patch, and my criticism is based solely on the fact that there did not seem to be much motivation added to doing Purgatory runs and I was hopeful that there would be.)

Original Review after about 40 hours of gameplay: This game is just fun. The followers are simple and adorable, the rituals and doctrines are extremely satisfying. This game takes all of the stimulation of a mobile-farm game, dumps all of the crappy parts about them, adds in some extremely fun roguelike-bullet hell flavor we all know and love from the Devolver catalog, and sandwiches it all together with amazing lore and a truly gripping experience. I may only have 19.8 hours while writing this review...but this is after another 26 hours on my Switch as well. (and all my PC time was spent in a single weekend binge)
The update that came out in late April added SO MUCH AMAZING post-game content...the game is a bit of a grind but I just love it so freaking much.

Cult of The Lamb is an absolute gem that seamlessly blends captivating gameplay with a unique and charming art style. As a fan of FPS and roguelite bullet-heaven games, I found myself immersed in a delightful world filled with challenging levels and intriguing mechanics.

The game's innovative approach to combining elements of different genres is refreshing, keeping the gameplay dynamic and engaging. The progression system is well-thought-out, providing a sense of accomplishment with each successful run. The balance between strategy and action is spot-on, making every decision count.

The art direction deserves special mention ‚Äì it's whimsical, yet it complements the game's darker undertones perfectly. The attention to detail in the design of characters and environments is impressive and adds a layer of depth to the overall experience.

Moreover, the developers' commitment to updates and community engagement is commendable. It's evident that they are passionate about their creation and are actively working to make it even better.

In summary, Cult of The Lamb is a must-play for gamers seeking a fresh and challenging experience. It's a testament to the creativity and innovation in the gaming industry. Highly recommended!

I can't really find a way to praise it anymore than just saying it's good, I can't really be bothered to go into detail about why it's good.

I do have some gripes, combat is kinda hard to get used to because its melee based in a 3d plane with 2d cartoon characters, so getting a hang of knowing when and where you and your enemies strikes are gonna land takes some getting used to, I honestly think the game would've been easier to pick up if it had 3d models in a cel shaded art style akin to Okami or Wind Waker, but this is not to say the current art style is bad which it ain't, it's fucking adorable and I love it. 

When it comes to the rougelike side of things it's pretty tame, you ain't gonna become an unstoppable demi god on a good run like in most other rougelikes but you are able to melt bosses if your good enough so I guess that's a plus, I do wish there was a bit more though, like I love the formula they got going on here but it feels like there's still more potential to be had in said formula, maybe a couple of updates will help that or maybe we'll get a sequel who knows. 

also side note and I know this suggestion gives me a couple red flags but I honestly thought the game would've been more violent, combat is already satisfying but it would've been more satisfying to see a limb fly off here and there, I know red flag but that's just me.

anyway buy it

Amazing rogue-like game, with endless replayability, up there with the likes of Hades and Enter the Gungeon. On the side there is this city building and worker management, which is almost as enthralling. But above all the art and music of this game are amazing. If you took the board game "Root" and smashed it together with eldritch horror and a kickass soundtrack, you have the art theme of this game. 

I don't want to say too much more as it is a much greater experience to discover all the other aspects this game as to offer, really giving you the feeling of a being given a second chance, discovering their new place in this strange world; stumbling and discovering into dominating and conquering. 

Gameplay: 9/10
Art/Themes: 10/10
Soundtrack: 8/10

I didn't think it was possible, but they did it. They made a botched PC port in the year of our lord 2022. Never before have I bore witness to a botched PC port of an indie game, but alas here it is. 

Oh boy, where to start? First of all, optimization. This is not a complex game, so naturally you'd expect it wouldn't be very demanding; and in the grand scheme of things, it isn't. Most of the time. I have regular stuttering and frame dips from just regular gameplay, but some screens (namely the upgrade screen) make my PC's GPU skyrocket all the way to 100% usage, and dips the frames to the low TWENTIES. Being my computer is far, far above the specs listed in the "recommended" requirements, this is really bad. Furthermore I know this isn't just my computer as it also tanks my Steam Deck; for which the game is VERIFIED. Same story with the stuttering and frame dips too. This was reported in the forums as far back as the game's release, and still occurs for some users (like me). 

Second is cloud saves, which have been completely botched. More minorly, the game does not sync data between Windows and Mac versions of the game. While this doesn't affect me personally, I do think it speaks to how little care was put into the PC version of the game. While it's [i]possible[/i] that the saves aren't compatible between versions, that almost never happens with Unity, so I don't believe that to be the case at all. More majorly, the game does sync graphics configurations onto other devices. How fun! Now the game goes completely ape-shit when I switch between PC and Deck because of the conflicting resolutions. How nice. This also means if you wanted to play the game on higher settings on one machine and lower settings on another, you don't have that choice since those options sync to the cloud! Not that you'd want to with the game's poor optimization, you really are better off keeping the game at low. This issue, like the prior one, has ALSO been an issue since release! Once again, no effort was made to fix it, even after all the content updates. Very cool.

As for critiques for the game itself, and this is very personal taste but I want to keep my review to the rule of 3, I never cared much for the artstyle. And no, I don't mean the weird snout-mouth thing some guys have going on. More I just think the "cute thing go scary" thing is wildly overdone, and this game does not try to set itself apart in any way. It feels like it goes way too hard with the overt edginess both in theming and in dialog, and most of my time playing it that wasn't spent gawking at my poor framerate was spent feeling just kind of turned off by the whole thing. It's super on-the-nose, but not in a funny, self-aware way; it feels like the game feels like the juxtaposition is way more original than it really is. Having the juxtaposed cult theme with a cute artstyle could work super well if the game had some better writing making it clear it knows the trope is overdone, but it doesn't have that, and it just feels...sad? Cringy? Gross? I don't know how to describe it, but it's some emotion between those three. I don't like it. Bottom line: I don't like it.

TL;DR because no one is going to read allat, game's performance is poor and some areas are obviously severely unoptimized, cloud saves were an afterthought that cause more issues than they solve, and the game's general juxtaposed cute-but-scary aesthetic is extremely overdone and the game brings nothing else to the table to make it feel original. Gameplay's fine, but somewhat generic as well and marred by these issues to the point that they really can't be ignored. For the price especially, I really can't recommend this game.

I'll start by saying something nice: I like the visual design. The juxtaposition of cute cartoon animals and edgy violence is what originally drew me in. That being said, Cult of The Lamb feels shallow.

Cult of The Lamb has two game modes, so I'll review them separately.

[h1]Combat & Dungeons[/h1]

Fighting and dodging little balls of pain while collecting random weapons in a dungeon full of square rooms just makes me wish I was playing Binding of Isaac instead, so I think it's fair to compare it to Cult of The Lamb. The random weapons don't synergize in interesting ways like the tears in Binding of Isaac. Unlike Binding of Isaac, this game has character progression with permanent skills and upgrades, which inverts the difficulty curve to make the game easier over time. Even without the upgrades, the highest difficulty in this game is a lot easier than Binding of Isaac.

[h1]Village Management & Tech Trees[/h1]

Managing your village doesn't have much to do with the combat. The two modes could have been two different games that you alt+tab between. Villager requests and buildings in your village require materials that can be found in the dungeon, but you'll always have more than enough if you spend a lot of time in the dungeons, so everything might as well be free. There are two tech trees to fill by managing a successful cult: one upgrades the village, and the other upgrades the Lamb. I found it too easy to complete all branches of both tech trees before I was even half way through the main story. Since the main story can only be progressed by fighting the bosses at the end of each dungeon, your reward for managing your village too effectively is to have a pointless village before the game is even close to over.

[hr][/hr]

Since this game is still actively updated, I hope the village management gets more depth and more meaningful interaction with the combat half of the game. Right now, it just makes me wish I was playing Binding of Isaac with one hand and Animal Crossing with the other.

It is a fun, but short, game. I had a lot of fun in my near 23 hours of game play with this title. That said, I really do not know what else to do. I have nearly 100% completion, and there is little incentive to play the dungeons again after you beat the game. You can continue to build your cult if you choose to, but the game offers little in the way of challenge or goals after defeating the end boss. The devs have mentioned Steam workshop mod support, so this may breathe some more life into this title.

Bit of a rant further down.

Been playing since Launch day. (Pre-ordered)
Good game for a rogue-like style. Poor balance choices though.

Golden Fleece being nerfed (I am still malding over this).
Heavy attacks still feel like ass, better to just avoid upgrading to not deal with shielded enemies (As they won't spawn if you aren't holding a weapon that has a Heavy attack upgrade).
Curses still steamroll this game (Blunderbuss seems promising as a "melee" replacement though, other weapons don't feel as powerful unless you have a specific tarot build, which is RNG).
Lv 10 follower cap meaning it's harder for new saves/players to gain inspiration when they start demanding nearly 1400 faith for a single god tear (For reference, my highest level follower is 63 before they implemented this cap, every time they pray, I get 63 faith out of them per cycle).

There is a relic that converts blue hearts into x2 diseased hearts but unless I missed something in my 70+ hours in this game, this is no downgrade at all. You just gain 2 diseased hearts (4 hits of retaliation damage) at the price of 1 blue heart (that does nothing but just soak extra damage). The fact this relic isnt a Fragile is a bit of a bonehead move.



Still rating this up if people are still seeking to play a rogue-like time-management game. Though if you hate either option, there are accessibility options that make the game easier to your liking.
Music's great, combat feels mostly smooth, healthy amount of collectibles if you are a collect-a-thon nerd (be aware some are uniquely locked behind special requirements like Twitch or PAX/Discord events. A Pre-order skin also exists. as of typing this review, this is currently unobtainable if you missed out.)

What is there left to be said, that hasn't been said about CotL? This game is fantastic, the people behind it are fantastic, the community is fantastic, it's one of those rare occasions where a game is incredible in all aspects. The team at Massive Monster set out with one goal that's pretty obvious to the playerbase, and it's making the absolute best game possible without cutting any corners. They have succeeded, and continue to succeed with every update they release.

I often get asked by people "If you have a problem with so many games, what do you consider a good game?" And honestly? This is my prime example. It's simply perfect.

I have loved this game for a long time, and was deeply excited for the most recent sins of the flesh update, but I have found that some of the changes made have sullied the experience a bit too much for me. In particular, the level 10 follower level cap seems like at best a lazy attempt at fixing the scaling issues in high level followers, and it ended up making one of the core mechanics of the game even more flat and boring than it already kind of was. I was hoping that the deciple system would be a prerequisite to achieving higher levels as a small way of adding more depth to putting in the effort to level a follower that far, but all of this has just left a bad taste in my mouth. Id still recommend this game to a new player even with the update, but I do think it's overall a worse experience. 
In general, I think that the cotl team could really benefit from rethinking their current balancing methods, as I feel that often times the approach is more to make it not strong than it is to make it more healthy for the game. The rebalancing of the 3 dice relics also shows this, as the issue with them before was that they were a button you got to press every minute or so to make yourself immortal, not that they were strong. Making them fragile relics doesn't fix the fundamental problem with them, it only makes them weaker and borderline unusable. Balancing updates should give you more options, not take away options. 
I do genuinely love this game and I deeply appreciate all of the work that's been put into this game by the developers, but it's because of this love that I worry about the direction the game is going in. This whole review didn't even touch on my issue with the sin system and how little it effects the wider gameplay for how many buildings and rituals are devoted to it, and while I love a lot of the ideas that went into this update I feel like a lot of it could have been implemented without the sin system at all and it would have fit in with the rest of the game much better. 
I hope that many of the balance changes are heavily reworked, or if not then completely revoked. I also hope that at some point in the future the sin system can be expanded upon to feel more intertwined and relevant to the rest of the game. I do think the balance changes are the bigger issue though, and I would be more than happy to change my review to a positive one if just those were fixed.

Note: I played about 50 hours of this game on Switch before getting it on PC

CotL is one of the most charming games I've ever played. It hits a very specific kind of whimsical eldritch demonic charm that is uniquely it. The music is great, the art direction is lovely, and the story and world are entertaining.

That being said it's gameplay can be a liiiiiittle shallow sometimes. It never feels HARD to maintain the Cult. Typically you have X problem, so you put Y solution on there, and it's more out of convenience rather than ever actually being a threat. Cultists are rather docile so even things like dissenters just get one or two days in the naughty corner before it's all back to basics.

The crusades (the dungeon crawling) has gotten a lot better though after the first major content update, though I'd argue there's still too few interesting enemies, fights, and items - especially when there's only around six different spells split up five ways into different elements.

However with the quality of the free dlc this game has launched I'm confident that this game will only get better and better with time, and that gradually all my little complaints will wash away. Still an amazing game even in its current state.

If you're religious, don't let the demonic setting and tone scare you away. Sure, you can commit a whole lot of sins in this game, but it maintains a strangely lighthearted feel of adventure. That tone is not taken seriously at all; it's just the weird world that the game takes place in. A world where the concepts of faith and power are reminiscent of irl groups, but not preachy or threatening to players. More often than not, most of the doctrines, rituals, and text come off as comedic reference to irl religious concepts and practices. In the end, this is just a game. What you do here does not reflect how you live in real life unless you let it, and you are not doing any moral wrong by playing it. So just have fun, lead your flock, wage crusades, and praise the lamb (game devs).

[h1]TL;DR[h1]
If you like colony sims/base building and/or action roguelikes this is a must buy.

Bought this game about two weeks ago during Steam Winter sale, I didn't have terribly high hopes, gosh was I incorrect.
Has become one of my favorite games to play after school/work, and I just can't put it down.

[h2] PROS : [/h2]
[list]
    [*]Lovely art style
    [*]Awesome OST
    [*]Cute, but dark
    [*]Gameplay is fluid and doesn't get stale
    [*]Game Time
    [*]Awesome bosses/quests
[/list]
[h2] CONS : [/h2]
[list]
    [*]Endgame kind of becomes a drag later on [b][u] (This might have been improved with the new Sins of The Flesh Update I will come back and update this review if so!) [/u]

    [/list]
[h3] Conclusion : [/h3]
Buy this game, it's worth your time and money, props to Massive Monster for putting out a wonderful game!

Took me a while to purchase this game, but I am sure glad that I did. It is the right mix of cozy base-building and rouge-like fighting. The balance is really up to you: go boldly into the dungeons non-stop, or hang with your townies only dip your toe in a dungeon to get a few coins.

Add to that an upgrade progression that lets you decide whether your townspeople will be enriched or sacrificed by your religious sermons.

I felt like the game design was very well thought out, which is so important for a base-building game like this one. You will spend tens of hours doing the same tasks over and over, so they have got to be fun or at least avoidable if you do not want it. I never felt that I was being pushed to do the "fishing mini-game" (yuck!) like so many other Stardew Valley clones.

I recommend this game at full-price, but then there are always sales and bundles for this game title. If you can get it on-sale, then it is a big thumbs up for fans of the base-builder genre.

I played this game on an Ubuntu desktop computer, and I also enjoyed the experience on a Steam Deck. Either way, the game needs to be played with gamepad controls.
