Played this on Xbox a year ago before switching to PC and loving replaying the game. A good mix of town management and roguelite especially the latter. There,s even options in the settings to pause time during your crusades (what cult of the lamb calls missions) so you can focus on combat without having to worry about your cult starving or getting sick while you're out and about slashing and casting curses at your enemies. Later in the game you can even sacrifice members to bring you back to life once a crusade and after beating the final boss and entering the post game the enemies and bosses even change which is cool. My favorite fleece is the cursed crusade since you can play as a pure mage and it definitely makes gameplay even better. Heavily recommend for anyone wanting to dip their toes into roguelites with a cute artstyle.

This game is a 6 or 7 out of 10. I'm recommending it, but it's very frustrating. 

The biggest issue is the game doesn't respect your time. I don't mean it's overly grindy- though it can also be that. The problem is how many unnecessary animations there are for EVERYTHING. Here's a short list of every time the game will stop what's happening and make you watch a 5 second animation:

-When you find a new card
-When you find a new blueprint
-When a boss appears mid level to talk to you
-Every.Single.Ritual. No matter how many times you do it.
-Every Sermon

The worst example is the last boss fight. You need to go through a summoning animation to start the fight, then the first two phases have a short cut scene/dialogue, and the final phase has a separate summoning animation. The game gives you a "Skip" button for part of the dialogue, so they're aware that sitting through it is obnoxious, but apparently just that one part. The rest is just TOO GOOD for us to skip past. 

Another issue is the fighting. They give you all of these choices as if you're going to want to theory craft builds, but it's so basic that you'll stop caring within an hour or two. Plus the power attack for the daggers is so OP that you'll find yourself stuck between two options:

1. Do I use something besides the daggers and actually put effort in?
2. Do I use the daggers and just try to finish the level/game ASAP?

Personally, I found myself leaning into option 2. And even if you decide you want to put effort in with the other weapons, the fighting is basic enough that I bet by the end of the third dungeon you'll be looking for your own low effort/fast finish setup. 

The town building is fun, but not hard. I played on hard difficulty, and there wasn't a single time I actually got into trouble in town. Instead, it just makes you babysit it very hard in the beginning. It can be a little annoying, but overall it's one of the better aspects. 

Beyond the gameplay, the art is solid and the juxtaposition of cute animals and cult sacrifices is fun. The story is pretty cliched, but it's good enough to keep you interested.
There are only two games I have ever platinum....the first one is Minecraft (don't judge me). The second is Cult of the Lamb. I have no regrets.
Dont wait a year to decide to give it a shot. There is a lot of content here and the gameplay loop has kept me coming back for over 34 hours and counting. Pick this game up.

Cult of the lamb is the quirky fusion of genres I never knew I needed. Smashing a quick-paced, aggressive rouglite crusade system together with a fun, adorable cult-building progression system, with a host of cute decorum and distinguished disciples, it all just works together so well. It has that unmistakable art-style that places it among the pantheons of indie darlings, and it's all bound together by a strange and mystical, yet indisputably amazing soundtrack. if you want a truly unique gaming experience, you've come to the right place. With the next big update, sins of the flesh coming, out tomorrow, there's never been a better time to join the cult of the lamb.

Ok so... yes this game is good. But I don't know if I've ever been so divided on my opinion of a game. This game is both exactly what the devs intended it to be and at the same time somehow has no idea what it wants to be. Let me explain.

The art direction = phenomenal
The sound design/music = perfection
The theme/lore/story = amazing
The gameplay = ... it's complicated...

I actually think the gameplay is really quite good. The combat is snappy and taking care of the cult is very engaging and fun. The problem I had was mostly a pacing issue I think.

I liked each game mechanic in isolation. But being on a crusade and having to stress about what's happening to your cult in real time... well that stressed me out and made it hard for me to pick up the game again or go on crusades because I was worried the minute I left everything would fall to shambles. This was obviously an intentional design decision and works perfectly with the theme they're going for so... yes the game is exactly what it wanted to be. And I had a hard time finishing it as a result.

And I guess that's fine. Two things can be true. I don't think this game will go down as my favorite game of all time as a result but I still really enjoyed Cult of the Lamb and look forward to toying around with future updates. I don't think I will do a full playthrough again for quite a long time though so here's hoping future updates give me more objectives to continue in my current save file.

Finally after all this time, the game has finally redeemed itself. Still angry that the game was released in an incomplete state, despite the devs lying that the game was complete.

That being said this game is quite fun. it has a very cutesy aesthetic, which is in contrast to the fact that you are the leader of an evil cult.  The game has two parts. The first part is a base management sim where you take care of a bunch of cultists and build a settlement for them to worship your character, the Lamb. 

The second part of the game is a rudimentary Roguelite where you battle monsters and collect resources, and cosmetics for your base. This part of the game reminds me heavily of the binding of Isaac, which is also a very messed up game with religious themes. It even has hearts of the same colors that do the same thing.
It still doesn't have any meaningful end-game content. After you unlock everything There is absolutely no reason to continue playing.  it takes about 12 hours give or take to do this. Once everything is unlocked, it's just about collecting endless resources for your base to keep your cultists alive. The rudimentary combat consists of Daggers, Swords, Axes, Hammers, and Gauntlets. There is also 25 magic spells called curses. There are also tarot cards that give you bonuses and abilities that change up the gameplay a little, but mostly all you'll be doing is swinging your weapon, and dodge rolling most of the time. Curses almost never come into play because the enemies and even bosses are ridiculously easy even on the hardest difficulty.  Finally there are cloaks you wear called fleeces that give you a powerful gameplay changeup, but at the same time give you a really bad disadvantage. One example of this is a fleece that allows you to draw four tarot cards before a run, but then you never get any more cards during a run. even with all these things the combat still feels empty and repetitive. 

If you are a bible-thumper stay away from this game as it will trigger your religious insecurity.

Truly a wonderful game that combines elements from both the Collectapedia and Resource Management genres while balancing them with elements from Roguelike Hack and Slasher games. There truly is never a dull moment with this title. Its extraordinarily well paced and superseded my expectations in every manner. There was never a moment where I felt as though my time was being dominated by a particular aspect of play. To achieve such a harmonious balance with as many gameplay features that this game contains can only be described as just short of genius. Progression feels natural. NPC stories sprinkle themselves in alongside your progression and there are times it grasps at your heart (pun not intended) to really engage the player and to make them question their actions.

Completeing the game probably won't take the average player more than 20 hours, but the post game content is just as engaging so expect to find 40-50 hours of enjoyment with this game. Also make sure to turn on Vsync if you know you'll be needing it because its not turned on by default. I had a bit of screen tearing but I don't mind sacrificing a few frames for a more whole picture. Unlike most titles anymore, this game's highest fidelity graphics are surprisingly undemanding provided how gorgeous they are, so I hadn't even noticed I was having issues on the graphical front until the first boss fight.

My only regret in my play through is that I wish I would've spent more time taking quests from the villagers. I will admit I was a rather cold and apathetic leader for these poor creatures, but it was hard to stay attached to any one for too long because of how short their lifespans were. Poor things drop like flies. Hopefully the coming updates expand the number of interactions you can take with them, and maybe give them tails? It just felt odd to me seeing animals without them.
Very fun, you easily develop emotional attachments so when they die it can be devastating.

This is an odd game to judge. It's absolutely addicting, though for all the wrong reasons. There is interesting progression, though with a total lack of precedence or substantial automation. There is both base building and top down rogue-like gameplay. However, both become rather shallow once you're a few hours in. There's just far too much babysitting and needless padding for me to really sit down and genuinely enjoy this game. There isn't a way to absorb all of the surrounding essence, and the cap for devotion is far too low on the main totem. You have to manually instruct your followers to do the most obvious of things, such as laying in bed to fight off a sickness. And these things constantly progress while you're in the dungeon. There are good ideas surrounding this, but the time element here just feels off. Famine events are unique and a step in the right direction for this type of risk/reward to adventuring. However, I feel that you have to hand hold far too much for these events to feel worth while. Combined with the generic stupidity of the NPCs, it can be difficult to spend more time out and about completing the actual quests rather than tending to gardens, cooking meals, and doctoring the ill.

This is hopefully another Devolver title that improves substantially with time. Enter The Gungeon wasn't released in any form near the masterpiece it became after a few years of patches and content additions. There is a listed roadmap for this game in progress, and I think the "sex" update that is to be released soon addresses some of these concerns. Time will tell.

With this said, I can't tell if this game was intended to be speedran - quickly slaying through all 4-5 of the dungeons - just to finish the game, resetting with new doctrine decisions or if it was intended to be this long grind to build up an ensemble of a cult like following. It supports both options, but in all honesty this game is probably best enjoyed plowing through the main content rather than scaling up your base for improved weaponry, relics, and curses. It's essentially a casual and cute game that's pretty to look at, but shallow on deeper consumption. The progression ends far too soon, and exists more as horizontal damage progression rather than providing enough new and unique ways to enjoy and play the game. It's enjoyable and fun initially, however I wouldn't recommend this game in it's current form for those who are more interested in the traditional difficult/rewarding rogue-like game format (ala Hades, Gungeon, Issac, Nuclear Throne, etc) which stand to still be enjoyable 200-300 hours in.

While not the worst game ever it just doesn't come together. The hook of running a cult to power up your lead is actually pretty bad. Most of what you do you your cult just goes to keep them running and automate some of the more tedious functions, which even then remains tedious do to a lack of simple management menus. The cult only powers up your character via sermons and the occasional sacrifice which just unlocks nodes on a relativity small skill tree. Most skills just unlock new flavors of the magic and melee weapons. I never really felt like I was getting stronger as my cult grew. 

The combat half of the game, and what you need to complete to roll credits, fails as well. The spells are decent enough but most melee weapons are too slow or too short to feel effective, the AX was the only weapon I actually enjoyed using. It also isn't a game were you can combine skills and become broken one way or the other, it's painfully basic. The art style, camera angle, and the amount of shit the shove in the foreground can make it a strain to look at and just obscures too much in the combat to push it. 

Both halves of the game come off as incredibly basic and don't mesh as well as you would hope. There are better action in this genre (Hades, Dead Cells) and probably more interesting sims too. The greatest failure is probably Dave The Diver does this combo with more charm and cohesion and I played that first, and I would recommended most people do the same.

An extremely shallow game with little replay value regarding both its major gameplay aspects: base-management and rogue-lite.  For example, the first time you can build a shelter for your followers that does not collapse is at the penultimate level of advancement for your base.  Most of the rogue-lite gameplay is chance-based, so there‚Äôs a minimal sense of advancement or improvement each time you venture forth.  

Great art style and atmosphere but little else of interest beyond the first few hours of gameplay.  

Overall, this game felt to me like it was two separate games that were being developed for the mobile platform that they ended up combining because they didn‚Äôt have enough substance to fully market either, and they somehow got the idea that they could pass off the amalgamation as a full-on indie PC game.  

I purchased it on sale with DLC (it just adds cosmetics) for around $17, and I still feel that the price was unjustified after having played it through.  Might be worth a couple of dollars, but, honestly, there are so many better games deserving of your time.

Cult of the Lamb's production value and art style do a lot of heavy lifting, but the repetitive gameplay ground me down after the 4th boss. I just wish CotL had whole-assed one style of gameplay, rather than half-assed two.

A wonderful mish-mash of genres consisting of classic dungeon crawling rogue-lites and sim-like base builders. Weirdly enough it works great, the game play loop is super addictive as you first delve into dungeons to conquer bosses, gathering materials and followers and then as you finish you get to your base to spend the resources, building your cult. The average run for a dungeon is about ten minutes as well so super easy to pick up at any time. Super easy recommendation and can only hope that Massive Games continue with this formula and pushes it a bit further as the only downside is that both genres can feel a bit surface level at times.

Positively delightful! As a gamer who is honestly not the best at gaming, I would say that this game is accessible for even those of us who live by the button smash. The relics update has added SO MUCH. I am loving the direction cotl is moving and I do have to say this is by far my favorite game. Genuinely, this is the funnest game I've played in a long time. I have to take breaks from games and usually when I come back to them, I don't feel as interested and invested in them. However, I haven't yet felt that way with COTL. There's a lot of replayability with this game, and the update has really amplified that. 
Which, by the way, for a game of this level of detail, style, and graphics, the constant stream of updates is a shocking. Each update is a delight, and I'm immensely grateful for all the work the programmers, artists, and other developers have put into this fantastic game. My score remains at a glowing 10/10.

Cult of the Lamb, developed by Massive Monster, is an enchanting journey that seamlessly blends captivating gameplay, charming visuals, and a unique narrative to create a truly divine gaming experience.

From the moment you step into the whimsical world of Cult of the Lamb, you are greeted by a visually stunning and intricately designed universe. The pixel art style is not only nostalgic but also serves to create a world that feels both mysterious and enchanting. The attention to detail in the character designs, environments, and animations is commendable, adding an extra layer of immersion to the overall experience.

The gameplay is where Cult of the Lamb truly shines. The combination of action, exploration, and strategic elements keeps you on your toes, while the clever use of roguelike mechanics ensures that each playthrough feels fresh and exciting. The game strikes a perfect balance between challenging encounters and rewarding progression, making it accessible to both seasoned gamers and those new to the genre.

One of the standout features of Cult of the Lamb is its narrative. The game weaves a tale that is both dark and humorous, creating a unique atmosphere that sets it apart from other titles. The quirky characters and unexpected twists in the storyline add depth to the overall experience, making it not just a game, but an engaging story to unravel.

The inclusion of the cult-building mechanic adds a strategic layer to the game, allowing players to customize and grow their cult in intriguing ways. It's a refreshing addition that enhances the overall replay value and gives players a sense of agency in shaping their in-game world.

Furthermore, the soundtrack deserves special mention. The music in Cult of the Lamb perfectly complements the game's atmosphere, enhancing the sense of immersion and contributing to the overall enjoyment of the experience.

In conclusion, Cult of the Lamb is a delightful surprise that manages to stand out in a crowded gaming landscape. Its combination of captivating visuals, engaging gameplay, and a compelling narrative make it a must-play for anyone looking for a unique and thoroughly enjoyable gaming experience. Massive Monster has crafted a gem that deserves to be celebrated, and Cult of the Lamb is undoubtedly a shining example of indie game excellence.

Do you love all things adorable and twisted? Look no further than this lovely little game. The animation is charming, the fighting mechanic is very satisfying, and the variety of activities makes sure my flitting brain always as something to latch onto. 

I do feel I need to clear up some comparisons that aren't really accurate, though. I'm an Animal Crossing player, and if you're going for that specific feel, you're really not going to find it here. Your followers will die of old age within hours, which means you really don't get to know them or get overly attached. It also isn't a real time game, which means the days go by super quick. I'd compare it more with Starview Valley in the mechanics department.

My biggest concern going in was that I would have to treat my followers like dookie in order to progress the game. Even though there are a few moments where you are required to make dark choices, they are few and far between. Mostly, if you wish to run a benevolent cult, you are given the option to do so. And you get to decide what that looks like.

Now stop overthinking it and give them your money! I'm glad I did.

This game is definitely a recommend from me.

The combat while yes very similar even between different weapons is still fun and engaging.
The storyline itself is wonderful, The base building aspects are done great, The rogue-like aspects are done great. The one flaw I'd say the game has is- replay ability. This issue has been lessened way way more as time has passed on because developers listen to reviews. [h1]A Darkly Whimsical Adventure[/h1]

"Cult of the Lamb," developed by Devolver Digital, emerges as an unconventional and intriguing blend of dungeon-crawling and religious management simulation. Set in a whimsical yet dark world, you play as a lamb resurrected by a deity named The One Who Waits, charged with building a following and combating otherworldly forces.

The game excels in its unique combination of genres. It splits your time between nurturing a devoted cult and embarking on dungeon expeditions. These procedurally generated dungeons provide a variety of stages to conquer, yielding resources essential for your burgeoning community. The game's loop of resource gathering, cult management, and dungeon exploring is surprisingly satisfying, enhanced by a charming art style and expressive animations that infuse joy into every aspect of gameplay.

Cult of the Lamb's storytelling and gameplay mechanics are its standout features. The game delves into themes of escapism, responsibility, and the complexities of leadership. The dialogues and interactions with NPCs are well-crafted, with each character adding depth to the game's narrative. The management sim aspect, involving resource gathering and cult maintenance, is well-balanced with the combat elements, ensuring a varied and engaging experience.

The game's combat system, while simple, is enjoyable and addictive. A variety of weapons and magical abilities add diversity to the battles, though the challenge may be mild for seasoned players. The enemies are well-designed, each with unique attack patterns that require strategic thinking and quick reflexes to overcome.

One of the game's high points is its presentation. The mix of cute animal characters with darker, satanic themes creates an intriguing aesthetic that is both endearing and unsettling. The attention to detail in the sprites and animations adds a delightful touch, bringing the game's world to life. The sound design and music are also noteworthy, enhancing the game's atmosphere with catchy tunes and character-specific voice effects.

The management aspect of the game is thoughtfully executed. Tasks like farming, sermon giving, and ritual performing add layers to the gameplay, intertwining base-building with the narrative's progression. The game cleverly uses these activities to deepen the player's connection to their cult and the game's world.

The game's world is not just confined to your cult's base or the dungeons. It expands to include various characters and locations, each adding to the game's rich lore and providing a welcome change of pace from the core gameplay.

However, the game is not without its flaws. The base-building elements, while engaging, can become repetitive, and the impact of player decisions on the overall narrative is limited. This lack of depth in decision-making affects the game's replayability.

In summary, "Cult of the Lamb" is a refreshingly unique game that successfully marries two distinct genres into a cohesive and entertaining experience. Its blend of dark humor, captivating art style, and engaging gameplay make it a standout title in the indie game scene of 2022. While it may not delve deeply into either the rogue-like or base-building genres, the overall experience is greater than the sum of its parts, offering a memorable adventure for players seeking something different.

THIS GAME IS MY FUCKING JAM

I played Cult of the Lamb earlier this year, and while I did love it, I finished the main story in a week and basically forgot about it until I realized there was a bunch of endgame stuff I didn't even touch and there were a bunch of achievements I didn't get
SO I PLAYED THE WHOLE THING AGAIN
And boy oh boy, was it amazing all over again. The game combines roguelite with base building, and it works PERFECTLY. You're gonna spend hours customizing your base down to every single tile, and then you're gonna go to the woods and beat the shit out of some heretics with some kick-ass gameplay and a PHENOMENAL soundtrack
Oh, and also, this game is METAL. AS. FUCK. You're a tiny little lamb guy that rules a religious cult in the name of an unnamed god made prisoner by his siblings and now you gotta set that mothefucker free, and while doing that you have an endless supply of followers that, as long as they have faith in you, will do whatever your dark heart desires.

This is one of the only games I've ever played where I just can't stop. I always have something to do, preach the daily sermon, set a new doctrine, fix the broken beds, tend to the farms, and then I get to the woods and the gameplay is so good I just don't wanna stop doing runs. I spend hours upon hours playing this and time just goes...

You can build your base however you want, as long as you keep everyone well fed, healthy and faithful to you. Of course, if there's not enough food, or if someone is trying to dissent against your teachings, there's always a way to make them change their minds... As the leader of your Cult, you can perform rituals that do all kinds of things, from forcing everyone into a fast so they don't bitch to you about hunger for a few days, to entire sacrifices in the name of The One Who Waits, or just straight up make your people do shrooms and get them so high they don't give a shit no matter what you do, so you can dance with them or just straight up murder someone in front of them and they'll literally not care

The game also has some amazing endgame where it gives you so much to look forward to and actually interesting ways of going back to places you've already visited, without it feeling boring. 
I will say that it would be a good idea to check the wiki or some online guides when it comes to certain doctrine choices, because with the right ones you can make your Cult extremely low maintenance and allow you to do some really long runs, but with the wrong choices, just a few minutes can make everything fall apart and make the overall experience very stressful, basically, the more you can avoid losing faith while you're away, the better (NEVER pick Good Die Young). 

Cult of the Lamb is yet again another certified Devolver classic, with the devs at Massive Monster still updating the game (sex update incoming btw).
I loved Cult of the Lamb, and if you like fun roguelikes and satanic shit, you're gonna love it too.

After what was probably one of the most enjoyable gaming experiences I have had in the last 2 years I felt inclined to write a review for this game. I spent a long time shrugging it off because I was worried that it might be trying to be too many things I'm interested in at once and thus fail to be what I wanted it to be. I was so, so wrong.

1) The music. I am such a sucker for a soundtrack and this has one of my favorite ones to date. The lighthearted songs that play while you manage your cults camp is the chefs kiss in this game and it makes things like farming, cleaning up, and other activities just so enjoyable. The track "Faith Up" literally gives me chills I find it so good. 

2) The art style is perfect for what this game is. It perfectly captures that cute but dark mood they are going for. Looks great on Steam Deck which is what I played it on and I would imagine even better if you play on the new OLED screen. 

3) The combat is by no means difficult (I decided to play on Normal for my first playthorugh) once you get a feel for the semi-bullethell gameplay most rooms offer. The weapons, powers, and relics are all fun and upgrades keep it fresh. I plan on upping the difficulty to its max and playing on the penitence mode (you unlock this through an in-game event) for more of a challenge next time since I have a grasp on the mechanics now.

4) Besides some important structures that help the game progress and expand your cult base building is as much or as little as you want to make it. I'm not a huge decorator and like minimalism so I kept my area simple but there is lots of potential for you to spend hours making your camp perfect. The UI for moving and changing pre-existing structures and building new ones is quick and effective.

5) I think the pacing of this game is perfect and it offers so many ways to play. For your first playthrough I recommend playing on the normal difficulty to just experience what it has to offer and keep things moving. Even fishing can be streamlined to auto-fish which I loved because I don't care for mini-games much. It's not trying to be too difficult but instead just be friggin fun. And since there is lots of ways to run your cult its also funny and dark. Want to make everyone the same name, eat poop, and fight to the death to be the rule enforcer? You can! And thats hilarious, but it also doesn't make the game impossible to beat just paced differently.

As others have said, the sum of this games parts is greater than the whole. And the whole is a fantastic game thats going to add the nookie soon. 9.5/10 buy it

Also, I really enjoy Penitence Mode. Having to handle the needs of followers, crusades, and the your own need to eat/sleep is fun without being overwhelming.

100% edit: after 50+ hours, I do enjoy the game, the art style, visuals, ambiance are just calming, perfect to be a game played casually. The main story is quite short if you speedrun it, but I do take my time with things. This game has quite the grind that can make people roll their eyes. The Purgatory sub-levels are a nice endgame and replayability option after one finish the game, although may not be enough for some. Overall, Cult of The Lamb is an amazing indie game, with a cute art style, cartoonish violence and world building elements. Thank you Massive Monster for making this experience like any other. I, myself, as a player, stand by you in this Unity nonsense.

It's alright.

A game that works much more heavily on the presentation than its execution. The game is really neat and has a unique dark vibe to it that makes it appealing, but the depth of its mechanics leaves much to be desired; the combat is incredibly simple, with very little trade-offs or tools to make it interesting beyond the RNG weapon drops and upgrades. The runs are extremely short, and they have to be because your cult runs in real time when you're gone.

A lot of the building and tasks in the cult-building mode is extremely simplistic, and really does not go beyond farming food and crafting food so your cult doesn't starve. A lack of in depth automation or random events happening makes the routine of this mode all the more boring fast, and eventually an afterthought.

But then you're left with a game where the rogue-lite element is too simplistic and made to be done extremely quickly and without much thought, and then you have a base-building element that is also extremely simplistic and you get a pretty average game. It's still good, just, nothing ground breaking IMO.

I'm gonna star by saying that cult of the lamb is a very fun game, if you're here for a complex story that's gonna change your life, this ain't your kind of game buddy, one of the most interesting things about cult of the lamb is the mix between being a rogue-like and also a base building game, it's the first game with these mechanics that I've ever seen or played, cult of the lamb knows how how to mix these 2 genres and make them very fun, I've played a lot of rogue-like games such as, the binding of Isaac, dead cells, and risk of rain 2, these are very complex rogue-likes with a lot replayability , cult of the lamb doesn't offer you that kind of replayability that other rogue-likes do, in fact the rogue-like aspect feels like a seconday aspect of the game, and it's more of a base building game in which you decorate your base and make your character stronger, the art style is amazing, it's probably what I loved the most about the game, the combat is very fun and you'll probably not get tired of it very easily, I reached a point where I knew the mechanics very well and the game just became tiring, also the fact that you need to take care of the cult members is sometimes very annoying, but overall is a good game that I would recommend to anyone.

Cult of the Lamb was set to be a winner for me. Combining management sim and roguelike mechanics is, on paper, absolutely my cup of tea. Cult of the Lamb does a pretty good job at executing this combo, but it's definitely not perfect.

The art style and sound design in this game are brilliant. It's wonderful to look at and really stands out from the crowd even as it sits half-in a genre that has other cartoon-y contenders; Binding of Isaac, primarily. At times, there are small visual elements which make combat tricky, such as white flashes for both hits on enemies and enemy hit charging times, difficulty with perspective in a strictly 2D environment, and issues with correctly reading hit boxes as a result, but none of this is game-breaking or frustrating enough to break the loop for me - I'd find myself playing for 3-5 hours at a time, unable to put the game down.

It's clear that this management sim / roguelike match is made in heaven, and as a result the biggest 'problem' with Cult of the Lamb is that there isn't MORE of it. And I don't mean lengthwise, I mean depth. As you reach the 15-20 hour mark, I found that the repetition was beginning to wear thin, and this is where the game's lack of depth begins to show the most. There isn't enough combat variety or depth in management systems to hold my attention much further in either halves of the game, so I pushed fairly quickly to the end and, following the credits, ran out of energy for achievement hunting, 100% completion, or new game attempts.  

I've been happy to see frequent updates and a DLC release since launch. It appears the devs take great care of their game and community and are giving it longevity where they can. The game's deserving of it, and I'd love to see what they could do with a Cult of the Lamb 2. Hopefully, they can take some time to push both the management sim and roguelike elements even further, as it's clearly a winning formula that I would love, love, love to return to.

A cutesy game with a casual cult-management side as well as a dungeon rouge-like combat side. 

The management portion of the game is pretty lightweight, you have to keep morale and food to acceptable levels while progressing through the building tree and completing objectives to appease your cult members. You unlock augments for your cult doctrine over time, though they don't impact the gameplay too severely. The cult members are fairly autonomous day to day, which is useful since the game's time continuously ticks away, no matter the activity.

The cult system is fine, but it's pretty shallow. Not a bad thing persay, just doesn't allow for much replayability. Then there's the combat sections in the dungeons which are pretty fun, if punishing. You roll a random weapon and ability for every floor of a dungeon, and you gain cards throughout a dungeon giving you minor bonuses until you eventually die or live to kill the boss at the end of the floor, unlocking the next floor. It's a satisfying enough system, if a bit repetitive. 

Recommend the game if you're a fan of the aesthetic and casual management games, look for a decent sale.

i like this game.

i think the way its portrayed online tends to lean into the humour, often with a memey twist, and while thats a part of this game, i think theres more to it than that. theres a balance struck. there are times where the atmosphere is dark and oppressive, the colours can be striking and visuals beautiful-- there are moments and ideas that i think, despite the humorous wrapping, can be quite poignant.

sometimes this balance doesnt work, and the game steps on its own toes. and i find that even on the developers/games social media pages, they tend to not even try to do so, and instead just focus on the funny, 'charming', marketable bits. but i do think this game is a bit more than that, if you let it be. and for what its worth, the gameplay loop is, to me, satisfying enough. im not particularly experienced with the type of combat in this game, so your mileage may vary-- i can understand if it might be a bit simplistic to people more experienced.

still, if it interests you, give it a shot-- theres a lot to like, even if theres occassionally some things to dislike.

Pros: Art is outstanding and very detailed, very clean animations, and idea of the game is really fresh and entertaining. Managing your own cult is really fun. Kudos to the artists.

But. The most important part of the game is combat - you cannot progress without it. And this is the place where this game sucks. IMO combat is too sloppy, with unpredictable positioning, frames\hitboxes and overall too slow and clunky in comparison to other similar games (BOTI, Hades for example). Also, where is clean interface for displaying fervor level? 

So, I would prefer to return this game despite its outstanding art style and idea, just because it is unplayable for me with current execution of combat mechanics.

Cult of the Lamb is a very grim yet charming entry in the "roguelite" genre.
You take the role of the Lamb, a creature tasked with operating a cult for an elder god being.
A very fun mix of town building, resource managing and dungeon crawling awaits. It never gets too much, with the "rogue" parts of the game being bite sized and taking about 10 minutes to complete (with an option to extend them, should you wish to do so.)
The game operates on a day-night cycle that can sometimes get a little repetitive with tasks that you should be performing every day, such as holding sermons and greeting your cult members, however it never got to the point where I would skip these tasks on purpose, as they don't take very long and give you nice perks.
As your cult grows you gain access to more difficult areas and a wider variety of decorations and functional buildings, as well as unlocking perks for your members and new rituals to perform.
Should you want to switch up the gameplay a little, the game allows you to change the Lamb's pelt, which gives them different buffs/nerfs, such as stronger attacks in exchange for taking more damage.
The story is simple yet engaging, and there is a lot of post-game content to keep you glued to your screen.
The developers have an update roadmap available, so there's always new features to look forward to. The mythical "sex update" is on the way at the time of writing. I can't wait~.
All in all, a very fun game and worth the pick up both on and off sale.

Also, there is a fishing minigame. Also also, you can, in fact, pet the dog.
if you like fighting and making hard decisions and having to make people happy than this is the perfect game for people like you.

Have you ever played Don't Starve or Don't Starve Together and wished that you could get NPCs to do some of the tedious work around your base and gather resources for you so you don't have to? Because that is basically Cult of the Lamb.

The biggest difference is that you personally don't actually need food or sleep, only your cultists do, so failure to manage them won't result in a game over, it mostly just sets you back in time. You unlock more and more buildings as you progress, and as you unlock buildings it unlocks jobs your cultists can do, so over time the things you have to personally oversee becomes less and less and more streamlined to deal with.

Taking care of your cult is pretty easy, it mostly just involves making sure they stay fed, manually sending them to "sleep it off" if they get sick, or imprisoning them if they start to dissent. The other half of the game is the roguelike dungeon crawling. Every dungeon run you start gives you a random weapon and a random spell, and you may upgrade or swap weapons and spells multiple times throughout a run, as well as picking up a bunch of different buffs from tarot cards and relics you find along the way. The only thing you actually have control over is your Fleece, and aside from your starting one that does nothing, all of them have bonuses and negatives to using them, so you can sort of change your playstyle based on what fleece you're using. My first unlocked fleece, and favorite until end game, was damage focused and gives a stacking 5% damage buff for every enemy you kill, but you lose the buff if you take any damage and you take double damage from attacks. At end game though, you get more hardcore versions of the starting fleeces, like one that makes you do 10x damage but you only have half a heart so you die in a single hit without mitigating factors. My favorite end game fleece though makes it so you don't get weapons at all and instead makes you a full on spell caster, letting your power regenerate over time, your spells cost less power to use, and you get a full bar of power every new room you enter.

Steam says i've played it 26 hours, which is hard to believe it has taken this long, but I had finally finished the post game content, although to be fair, the post game content is mostly just running through the normal game a second time with everything a little harder but using overpowered new fleeces to make it not even matter.

All in all, I enjoyed the game. I bought it for $15 on sale and its definitely worth the price for me. I didn't bother with the DLCs because they only add cosmetic stuff like follower skins and new decorations, which I didn't care about at all and still don't regret not buying them.

That said, i'm probably done with the game. There doesn't seem to be a whole lot of replayability, and you technically have to play through it twice to really finish up anyway. At this point, there is nothing left for me to do but run the dungeons over and over but I don't get anything useful or interesting as a reward anymore (since I have already got all the stuff I want) and the runs aren't unlimited anyway because theres only a finite number of rooms until it ends each time, there is no infinite run possible to see how far you can get or anything like that, which is kind of disappointing.

Either way, I think i'm done with it, but i'm glad I got it and got to experience it. Cute game. I'll come back and check out the new update that is in the works and supposed to be coming out soon, maybe it'll add more fun stuff to do.

Cult of the Lamb combines elements of roguelites and town sims. This is a good idea on paper, but their implementation missed the mark. I had these feelings very early in the game, but kept playing hoping it would improve.

IMO the developers did not really understand the roguelike/roguelite genre, and ended up making something that appeals more to the casual gaming audience. 

To sum up the main problem: the town sim exists to prevent you from playing the roguelite.

Time continues to pass for your townsfolk whenever you are doing a run, this leads to you losing 1-2 days per run. Missing days translates to various missed opportunities/resources. Also, you must provide your townsfolk with food constantly or they will starve. The result for me was frequently spending 3+ days between runs to minimize losses before going on the next run. That is 20+ IRL minutes between runs, doing chores.

A lot problems could be forgiven if the the roguelike elements weren't so bland. I am not a very skilled player, but I enjoy the genre from time to time. For this reason, I chose the "normal" difficulty. In my hours of playing, I have not died once. Not a single time. There were 2 times when I got down to 1/2 heart, but only because I was lazy. The amount of invincibility on the roll is way too high, and most enemies are slow + melee. Boss battles are often solved by tanking their hits while spamming your melee weapon mindlessly. Despite looking like an isaac clone, it lacks much in the way of nuance and challenge.

Overall, this game has a lot of potential, and the developers clearly put in a lot of work into the aesthetics. But it is not "fun" to play.

THIS GAME IS BONKERS. It is everything is advertises itself to be and more: a perfect mesh of fantasy, fright, hack & slash, and dark humor.

Gameplay is easy enough to figure out, as are the objectives. Activities to manage your Cult keep you active and the story itself is quite immersive; it is easy to suddenly realize you've been at it for over an hour. Speaking of which, it is a game which very much discourages dawdling; even in non-critical activities, you are often up against the clock, as it should be. Staying engaged is its own reward. While there are no overtly measured timers, many things do decay, spoil or wither.

In terms of technical gameplay, it is rather one-note, but you'll hardly notice because what it does, it does very well.

The world in which it takes place is interesting and there is so much mythology and implied history, with the addition of some other aspects to exploration in gameplay, Cult of the Lamb has a great deal of world building potential. This game certainly deserves a sequel or massive expansion.

This is a bit of a personal no, and I get the feeling it might only be a no because Dave The Diver got there first (in my purchase queue). They're both basically the same thing, a very slick, well presented collection of skinner-box tasks built around a rogue-like "main" activity. The key difference being that Dave the Diver rewards me, in particular, with some absolutely wonderful characters, cut-scenes and story. This rewards me with a bit of a second rate Dungeon Keeper-esque experience that smacks of epic reddit bacon, for some reason.

I can't force myself to go back to it anymore, and while 8 hours for 10 quid or whatever I paid is a fine bargain, maybe it isn't one that you'll want to make. Who knows.

I've played a few Rouglikes now and Cult Of The Lamb is certainly up there with some of the best, the combat is fast and explosive, with lots of different paths for different weapons, curses, and other bonuses along your runs like Tarot cards. The bossfights are a bit easy for the majority of the game, so I reccomend you turn the difficulty up, but the final bossfight does pose an actual challenge, and you will have to be strategic with what you have and how you use it.

The main draw to the game for me was the cult features, which sounds insane to type. The world outside the dungeon crawling combat arenas is really where I had the most fun, recruiting and managing all of my cult members, creating an amazing looking village, and overall the day to day gameplay loop of the cult was more interesting to me than the combat even though it was still strong. Overall expect ~20 Hours for 100%, 15 for completion.

Couple a decent combat system with a fantastic, vibrant artstyle, along with some great building and cult-sim mechanics and you have one of the best rougelike/lite games I've played in a while. 8.5/10

I bought this game because a friend recommended it, played for a few hours and realized how screwed I was because I wasn't playing with a controller. It felt incredibly difficult and frustrating. Bearing in mind, all of my games on Steam I have not used a controller, but also that this game is unlike any other I have in my library.

I set it down for a few months, picked up my husband's bluetooth Xbox controller, and then ended up no life-ing the game for a couple weeks. Like I mentioned, this game is unlike any of the others in my library. I play a lot of simulation, tycoon, management, cozy games. But this story-rich, roguelike dungeon crawler with a touch of life management stole my heart. I love this game, bought my own Xbox controller so I'm not always using my husbands, and continue to no-life the game on and off. Am I good at it? Sometimes, but I'm getting better.

Are there specific pros and cons to the game? Not to me specifically; the game is very well rounded with updates and content still being released. It's a labor of love and the devs obviously love their game. There are occasional bugs and visual glitches, but they are easily reportable and seem to be taken care of quickly.

I would highly recommend this to anyone who wants to spice up their game library, or if you already know you like this type of game. It's a fun play with lots to do and an interesting spin on the genre. 
[b]Please please please play with a controller for the best experience![/b]

I will segment this review into two parts, the quick part for those who want to know if the game is good or not and the bigger part.

Spoiler free part
Summary: I would recommend if you like dungeon crawlers and roguelike games

Cult of the Lamb is a dungeon crawler (binding of Isaac or enter the gungeon) combined with building strategies (timberborn). And this combination is to my surprise well made and fun. Theoretically, you can dump the base building if you don't like it but I can assure you, you will like it. Combat is swift energetic and can be quite challenging (depending on which difficulty you're playing). There is some story but I would say it's not that big but the devs say they're working on it. And finally, I would like to say the "simple drawn" graphics are just amazing. That's what I like about indie games, they're unique style of art and in this scenario, it works wonders. (when your cute little lamb performs a ritual where you sacrifice your cute little cat follower and your other followers start clapping and cheering it is just wonderful XD)

The long analysis
The base building aspect
I generally like this experimental combination of genres, but I must say I enjoyed the vision of the cult growing for like the 2 or 3 locations and didn't really bump into: "You need more cultists to open this door" but at the end of the game you need about 20 cultists to progress, so I needed to grind. There are rituals and other things but I really did not pay much attention to them (that doesn't mean they're not fun but I enjoyed more the combat side). But that's just me.
The dungeon crawler aspect
So in Cult of the Lamb, you go to crusades for materials and to kill bosses to progress in the main story. I really like how different the scenery and enemies are in the four parts of the game. There are many playstyles you can choose, you can have a "mage build" or just depend on your demons to do all the work or you just hack and slash, That is for you to choose (if the RNG and cards are right). There are four weapons you can get at the start of your crusade and all of them have unique playstyles and abilities for you to master. So the crusades don't get repetitive and every crusade is unique in its own style.

All in all cult of the Lamb is a great game and you should play it, or I might send some very hungry fellow your way :).

Short story, Spoiler alert
[spoiler] You are the last of your kind, the last sacrificial lamb. The four bishops of the old faith want to kill you to get rid of a prophecy. They kill you and then you meet in the afterlife with One Who Waits. He gives you a Red crown that gives you immense power and commands you to make a cult in his name. Then you return to the land of the living with a quest to kill the four bishops to release One Who Waits. When you do kill all the bishops then you need to go to the afterlife and make yourself a god by killing your master. [spoiler]

As someone who seldom plays single player games (especially rouge-like type games), this has become one of my personal favourite single player games to date! 

What I like: 

- Has an enjoyable gameplay loop that bounces you from managing your village that is easy to understand and not "micro-managey" to fighting in rouge-like dungeons and like side quests and tasks in-between to make the game refreshing

-Has a killer sound track that has the mix between cutesy (think Animal Crossing) with a more sinister and dark tone. It fits the game extremely well with every dungeon type and area having a completely different vibe. 

- As someone who can be quite sentimental towards the characters in games, being able to not only choose your cultists' names and facial appearances, but having different decisions made for you to make to each cult member leaves you with moments of going, "Awww, do I really want to sacrifice you for _____?". I have some favourite cult members but don't tell the other please. D:

- There is always something to do in this game, it feels like most of the time I complete a task, there's always something else I could do after. Even after defeating the final boss, there seems to be a good amount of things to do after the game but I have yet to play that. 

- The relics that have been added with the previous major FREE update is a very welcome addition. Relics are one or multiple use abilities that have big effects. These can include giving the lamb a random set of health via a dice roll to decreasing the lamb's size, making him faster with a smaller hitbox. 

- Enemy types are varied for each dungeon type which reflect the types of bosses you will fight as well. Some are not as unique with most having unique ways of attacking. Everything from little guys hiding in bushes to conceal their attacking animation and ambushing you, to toads that upchuck red heat-seeking bee's

- The story is kinda cookie cutter, nothing mind blowing but it's the type of story you would want out of a more chill game like this. 

- S-X UPDATE?????


What I dislike: 

- Some of the tarot cards (buffs you gain while in a dungeon) you earn can sometimes be kinda useless compared to the rest. Having cards better than others will obviously happen but one's such as "makes you break rocks by standing near them" is a lot less useful than gaining a "1.5x damage boost with your weapon"

- The final boss fight was cool but I wish I could've customised my loadout before fighting him. Instead you're tossed into an RNG scenario of hoping you get the weapons and spells you want to use. 

- I recommend getting the "outhouse" building ASAP when playing the game as it can be very annoying at first to pick up your members' "fertilizer". I wish you could acquire it sooner so I'm not spending a large chunk of time cleaning up after them when I could be doing other things instead. 

- Because of the unique Paper Mario like aesthetic, the hit boxes can sometimes be hard to follow. There have been many moments, especially at the start of the game, where projectiles and enemy attacks seem to hit you in awkward spots. Not too much of a big deal, it's something you will just have to adjust to. 

- Some of the enemies which you would think would be easy to fight can ironically be the most annoying. One dungeoun features flying bats that are not only quick but can attack at a very ridiculous range imo and even fly out of bounds to where you can't even attack them! 


Overall thoughts, the game is fun that offers FREE major updates with a lot of content even after defeating the final boss. Very much worth the original price but is a nice steal when on sale :>

*In short: This game is amazing! Probably one of the best I've ever played, really.*

Cult of the Lamb is a rogue-like game centered around building your own satanic cult and indoctrinating cute forest animals to grow your divine powers, which will come in handy when you venture in the lands of the Old Faith to fight against false prophets in a dungeon-crawl like experience. You play as the LAMB, a poor sheep who was brought from the dead by THE ONE WHO WAITS to eliminate the false gods and restore his powers. In your way you gather gulible cultists to hear your sermons and follow your word.

First and foremost, the artistic design for this game is simply put: PEAK. The environments, the characters, the animations, all of it is extremely original and well made. The cartoony and cute aspect of the characters clashes against the dark theme and rituals performed by our lord and savior, the Lamb, making it a really fun and impressive game to play! As an amateur artist, this game's art really inspires me!

The gameplay is also phenomenal! Not only does the base building aspect not feel just slapped onto the game, but it also is quite fun and enthraling, for I catch myself just running around my cult doing chores, tending to my followers and editing building just for the fun of it! The combat is great, involving mainly being able to dodge enemy attacks and memorizing boss attack paterns. It provides a challenging yet rewarding experience for those who like crusading against the infidels in proceduraly generated combat rooms. Although I must warn you that this game is better played using console controllers (I play using my ps4 controller).

On top of all that, the soundtrack is also really great! It perfectly fits the setting and is actually really enjoyable. The songs feel whimsical and mysterious, and it's really fun to watch the lamb just swaying around whilst the background music plays lol.

To add even more compliments, the developers of Massive Monster are always in contact with their community and never cease brewing up quality updates and bug fixes to present the best game possible. 

So yep, I really do recommend it. The only downside I could possibly say about this game is that it can become repetitive as you grow your cult... but honestly I don't even feel that, everytime I open this game I usually spend several hours playing without noticing! And after the Relics of the Old Faith free dlc dropped, even the endgame got new chllenges and content!

Played through 'Cult of the Lamb'.  This is a game with a very fun premise - build your own cult, slay the opposing gods, and obtain power by any means necessary - including sacrificing those who dare defy you.

The game is INCREDIBLY charming.  Your cult members are adorable little animals that make fun noises.  The art is fantastic and does a great job of making you forget just how dark the subject matter is.  The sound design is just as good, mimicking the whimsy of the art style.  Combined, these make what could easily be a game that's far too depressing, dark, and scary into something fun to pick up and play.

Sadly, art and sound are the best part of the game.  The core loop of the game is spent 1) building your base 2) manipulating your followers to love you and gather resources 3) going out into the combat area of the game to collect more resources and followers.  When you return from combat, repeat.  Simple!

Both the combat and the base-building parts of the game are lackluster.  I completed the game without bothering to build more than half of the buildings and never suffered for it.  The base building and cult management felt like spinning my wheels for the purpose of spinning my wheels:  I need more followers to harvest more resources to support more followers which requires more resources.   Luckily, this doesn't take TOO much time or thought, and even though it wasn't great, it didn't drag the game too badly.

The combat, which is a huge part of the game, also feels lackluster.  Your kit consists of an attack, a dodge roll, a spell, and a heavy attack.  This seems like a fine enough kit for a game like this, but the game doesn't challenge you enough to truly master anything.  Most of the time, I was just mashing attack while dodging the enemies' telegraphed attacks.  The combat was so trivial that the rare times there was a more difficult fight felt like an absurd difficulty curve spike, but really I just needed to dodge a little better.

There's a few inconsequential side quests, a gambling game, and a fishing game that serve no real purpose and aren't entertaining on their own.  You can give gifts to cult members, inspire them to dance, turn them into demons and bring them into combat with you, marry them, force them to eat poop (yes lol), but all of this micro stuff is unnecessary.

Overall, I spent about 15 hours going through the game on 'hard' mode.    I did enjoy it for the most part, but nothing is compelling me to go back for another spin.  It's a very strange game that acts like it's going to challenge your micro and macro abilities, but the low stakes involved and the simplicity of combat make me feel like the developers designed a game to truly test you, then pulled back at the last moment.  What a shame.

You are a Lamb who was excecuted, and brought back to life, and now you‚Äôre a cult leader, seeking revenge upon those who killed you, and free the one who brought you back.

Cult of the Lamb is a cute game with cute character designs, and it‚Äôs weird how well it fits with it‚Äôs dark theme (sacrifice and death etc).
It has nice soundtracks, and it‚Äôs combat mechanics are just smooth, it feels really good to play.
The gameplay alternates between hardcore fighting and chill cult management. You can easily forget about life for hours straight while building, upgrading, preaching and playing god on your cult.
I never used it, but it has a nice Twitch integration, you can name your followers after your real Twitch follower‚Äôs usernames, and they can vote about decisions in the game. It‚Äôs the closest thing to really playing with the chat.
From the beginning it‚Äôs very addictive, it has a nice progression and an interesting enough New Game +, making the monsters harder, and adding new moves to the bosses, a new gamemode and depending on your late game choices, a more complete conclusion. it‚Äôs worth playing.
It‚Äôs very creative the fact that each character has their own fictional language, for us it‚Äôs just some random goofy noises but it makes sense in that world.
 I played only on Extra Hard and it was challenging, maybe I could‚Äôve 100% it way sooner on easier difficulties.
Where the game really shines is your freedom of choices, what kind of cult leader you‚Äôll be, and even having so many possible solutions for the same problems, for example: Your followers are hungry. You can: harvest berries and cook something; go fishing; unlock upgrades that let you make food out of grass; make a feast ritual; make a ritual where they will not eat or be hungry for 3 days; decrete that cannibalism is acceptable so they can eat dead followers meat... it gives you a lot of autonomy and freedom.
Thre are different possible gamestyles with your fleeces and curses, whether you want to play like a mage focused on using curses, or maybe equip a berserker fleece that makes your hits 10x stronger but you die with 1 hit of anything. There are a lot of options and each one is very different and fun to try.
I‚Äôve been wanting to play this game so bad, and it was really worth the price.

Cult of the Lamb is a game I have spent a solid amount of time playing and grinded for all achievements on. During that process I experienced the game fully and explored many aspects of game play. Over all I would say Cult of the Lamb is a good game worth playing the combat and town building aspects of the game both are fun.

   However it isn't a game without issues for me at least during the start of the game having to manage cult members was incredibly annoying and time consuming and I often found my self just wishing to get back to the dungeon crawling. That being said later in the game you can automate maintaining your cultist and it is very fun to fully build up and decorate your cults town.

   The combat or "crusade" sections of the game are fun with smooth combat and movement, the bosses are fun and it is fairly challenging especially later in the game. Post game you can replay through the dungeons on harder difficulty all in a row which is a fun post game challenge. Unfortunately I found that while trying to beat the game at certain points the requirement to progress being number of cult members led me to simply rush through the easiest dungeon hoping for cult member spawns which was very tedious and boring.

  The bosses them self's are very fun and the combat lends itself to being able to specifically opt for a certain combat style. That being said while I do understand its listed as a "rouge-lite" it was getting repetitive by the end of the play-though there's effectively only 6 weapons and 7ish curses. Instead of adding new ones the game opts to simply put a new effect on an existing weapon as the "new" one. However if you don't mind the somewhat limited options I'm sure you will find the combat very fun as I definitely did.

  I think that while it does have its issues cult of the lamb is a very good game with a distinct style that sets it apart from other rouge-likes and if your looking to dip your feet in the water its a good start. But if you want a lot of variety and intense fast combat it might not be the game for you.

   I would give it a 7/5/10

I wish there was a mixed option. It's not a bad game, but it's really not that fun either. If you like all the chores parts of Stardew Valley mixed with extremely short runs of Binding of Isaac but without the interesting mechanics that make each run unique, then you'll like this game. This game feels like a shallow version of a bunch of better games smushed into one wide but extremely shallow package. Plus there's no good way to automate all the extremely boring and repetitive parts of the game. 

Days are really short as well so half the time it felt like all I was doing was tidying the base, transferring poop from the outhouse to the fertilizer, blessing everyone daily, etc and before you know it the day is over again and you have to make a ton of meals and get ready for the day again. Plus, if you take your time on a run, then by the time you get back everyone is starving, faith is in the dumps, and you have to do more chores to get everything back on track. This is really just trying to find time to actually play the game in between all the chores, but when you consider only the time it takes to actually play the game it's only a couple hours long.

Plus all the unskippable animations for thinks like blessing followers, adding cultists to your base, etc really got on my nerves by the end.

Not feeling so kind? Make them fight to the death for your amusement, imprison dissenters, sacrifice them, murder them, make them cannibalize each other, sacrifice them so you may grow stronger.

I can't believe I haven't written a review for one of my favorite games yet.

Cult of the Lamb is a great mashup of civilization builder and roguelike action. One half is cultivating your plot of land for your cult, building structures, harvesting resources, making sure followers have their hunger, hygiene and faith needs satisfied. The other half is spent on "Crusades" where the Lamb enters the realms of the Old Faith to fight heretics and collect resources for their cult back home.
The action is about halfway between Hades and The Binding of Isaac, where it has Hades' close range combat, a dodge roll, and a limited "cast" ability. It is like Isaac in that the health system is nearly identical, with red gray and black hearts, all having the same function. The Relics update adds active items that can be activated, then need to be recharged by fighting enemies, similar to Isaac space bar items.

The developers at Massive Monster have been keeping the game very interesting with regular updates and new content. I respect their desire to make the game the best version of itself, rather than move on to the next game, and leave CotL in the bin collecting dust. I reccomend following CotL on twitter too, their social media manager is a riot.

Once development officially ends, I'd love to see CotL get a Steam Workshop page. Unleashing the fanbase on follower forms, weapons, enemies, and levels could be extremely entertaining.

I've played this game at two different points in it's development cycle, but still feel the same about it as I did at release even after countless updates. I think this game is incredibly buggy and It's combat elements require more depth if it should be looked upon as a roguelike or even roguelite. 

On release I thought the game was interesting, but disappointing. The concept of managing the needs of your cult while balancing the time to venture into dungeons to further the story is cool. Though I think both aspects of this balance are flawed because of how the cult managing aspect is incredibly easy and the combat aspect of the dungeons is janky, which makes it difficult. I think the combat in this game is exceptionally frustrating from the fact your moveset on each weapon is very limited and your dodge roll is unreliable. On release your moveset was a single combo, a dodge roll, and a button for using your curse attack. This is very underwhelming and not very fun. The weapons definitely feel different, but not in a meaningful way that makes me invested in the system or have a weapon I prefer. This is paired up with the fact that the range enemies can hurt you at isn't clear and becomes impossible to judge when certain moves come out so quick. Along with that there's a dodge roll that is way too slippery to be very helpful at weaving between enemies or dodging projectiles (which the game makes you do a lot of later). Because of that every bossfight or difficult encounter feels like a frustrating mess because of how unprecise the dodge roll feels and the way some weapons insist on finishing a combo for extra damage that stops you from cancelling it with a roll to avoid getting hit. This is to say the roguelite aspect of the weapons is very limited and I would say the same about the tarot cards in this version. you'll get at least 2 tarot cards every run, but the way they modify the game doesn't change the way you play it at all and so doesn't create the image of this game as an interesting roguelite.

I mention this Roguelite stuff a lot because if you google this game and ask if it's a roguelite most places will come up as yes. As someone who has played a lot of roguelites good and bad, I felt tricked and lured in by the games weak and surface level mechanics that I hope would give the game some depth later. But honestly the city builder aspect feels like the more polished part of this game because the amount of strange glitches and softlocking this game's dungeons have is upsetting. Some of the glitches can just be an enemy not giving a clear visual tell they are doing an attack, but sometimes it can be a strange softlock that prevents you from finishing a dungeon and forces you to start the whole run again. Sometimes if enemies live after the boss died or you get damaged in someway while your in the middle of picking up the boss's item it's over for you. You will now be stuck in a hell of not being able to finish picking up the object and the walls sealing the room up so you can't progress. The only option being to exit out through the menu and start the dungeon again. Of course these are issues I had at release so they can get fixed or improved on in the future ideally, but the reason I'm doing this review is because it hasn't.

After getting Softlocked on one of the big bosses of the game (the third dungeon's Bishop) I took a break from a game. It just felt too unpolished and buggy to enjoy in it's current state so I waited for over a year to come back to the game. Which I will say did thankfully add depth to the combat and roguelite mechanic through giving each weapon a unique button to do a special move with that only consumes a bit of curse meter. Along with that, more fun tarot cards were introduced and they added relics that were bound to a button you could use inside the dungeon that have a variety of effects. This is an upgrade, but all the special moves (including the ones that come out quickly) lock you in place really hard and make you an easy target so you are discouraged from using them. Also it takes a while to unlock all the new tarot cards so most runs have you using the boring ones from release. Still an improvement though despite the amount of bugs that still exist inside the game. It only took me 3 hours of playing this game again to somehow get myself totally softlocked into a boss room again. Being forced to quit out of the menu and restart the dungeon. Because of this I think the combat is too frustrating and or inconsistent thanks to bugs to be fun to play with.

I'm leaving this review not because I hate the game or anything, but because I don't want anyone coming into this game expecting something like an interesting roguelite and getting disappointed by the combat aspect of the game. I still think there's fun to be had in this game if you know what you're actually getting into with it. False advertising on it mainly being a roguelike was the reason I bought this game and so it's what is important to me covering here. It would take a lot to make me try this game again, but I hope my current perspective to those who glance at this game and check the reviews before buying.

I bought this game on Switch when it first came out and I'm pleased to say I am a happy convert - I especially enjoyed meeting the creative team at PAXAUS! It's great to see a homegrown indie game have such great success, and I think the combination of the crunchy playstyle, gorgeous and creepy-cute art, and the absolutely stunning soundtrack by River Boy are what makes it such a wonderful game.

Also, shout out to the accessibility features - this game was my first ever rogue-lite, and my first ever that wasn't turn-based in some way! With the difficulty grading and ability to tailor the game play to my needs, CotL acted as a gateway that soon got me playing more difficult games like Hades! So it will forever be a favourite and a comfort game for me that gives me a much needed pick me up whenever I play!

Cult of the Lamb nailed the aesthetic of having a cult: On the outside, it is friendly and caring, and your leader gives you food, protection, and a place to sleep, but on the inside, the cult is dark and corrupt, and the same leader, you though is a friend or a father figure, can sacrifice you no matter how loyal you are. 
The whole game¬¥s art style is cute-looking, but with a dark undertone, it¬¥s beautiful. 
Music also helps create this atmosphere of calmness and harmony, but when the action starts, it can drop some great beats.
Combat is swift and precise. Thanks to the DLC, the combat is even more harder and has many things to complete and gather, like bishops as your followers.
The only complaint I have is the end game with your followers and buildings. There needs to be more stuff to build and upgrade because there is nothing much you can do after you build everything available. The same thing is with your followers as there is nothing much to do with them, mostly used for prayers and farming.
Other complaints are sometimes the game crashes during rituals, and sometimes the game lags when a lot of things happen at the same time, but it is not game-breaking stuff.
All in all the game is just terrific. 
Go, become a great leader, and destroy all the unworthy heretics!
