... Still a positive review though.
[i]Barely.[/i]


All jokes aside, the cult of the lamb is a game with a great art directory. The game excels at it's great artstyle, music and sound effects but is blood-boilingly mediocre in every single other regard.
Because of this I sadly cannot rate this game higher than a 6/10, despite having the potential to have easily been an 8/10.

Cult of the lamb is based around the interesting idea of combining a dungeon crawler rogue-lite with a colony-sim but fails miserably at both in the process.

To start it all off: 
The game is glitchy at times, thankfully it is rare, but when it does happen it does tend to be quite big.
An example from my playtrough would be the temple building: 
This is the biggest and most important building in the game and you are supposed to only be able to build one of them in your colony. In my playtrough I somehow placed 2 of them at once on the same spot overlapping eachother. 
After that, everytime I went into my temple the game would load the interior twice after a delay, creating a really annoying short wait I have to sit out every time I enter.
Eventually I moved the temple to hopefully fix that issue, that was when I discovered I somehow built 2 of them inside eachother, moving one of them fixed the issue but created a new one: the duplicate temple still existed and cannot be destroyed. With the duplicate temple being stuck in the place it was, I permanently lost a decent chunk of my colony landmass. 

Secondly, the colony sim part of the game I can only describe as boring as hell, I sadly lack the ability to describe why exactly but the best I can do right now is say that the entire colony just feels like a way to grind for grinding sake instead of creating a truly living society.
Likely because the NPCs are incompetent and cannot do almost anything without the player instructing them to.

The amount of unskippable animations or 'cutscenes' in this game gets frustrating very quickly, there are hundreds of unlocks in this game and for almost all of them you have to go trough a 10-second animation, this is okay at first but dear god does it get agonizing quick. 
Same applies to shorter animations that you see very frequently such as increasing the loyalty of a follower to your cause.

It feels as if the entire game is based around the gimmick of "cute artstyle but dark evil story", 
which isn't necessarily a bad thing but where the game does start to feel incredibly lazy is that it starts feeling like an excuse or distraction for the mediocre gameplay.
"Oh the colony is boring as hell but look over there! they are doing some messed up sh*t over there! damn ain't that awesome?! It's completely messed up but our artstyle makes it look so qute! Please ignore that there is barely anything to do!"
>repeat for the entire game.

Now let's talk about the roguelite dungeoncrawler part of the game!
As with everything else, the music, art and sound effects are great, but utterly mediocre or bad in all other regards. 

1. A horrific shortage of weapons and abilities:
COTL might very well be the roguelite with the lowest weapon variety I've ever seen (and I play a LOT of roguelike/lites)

It's literally just these:
A Dagger
An Axe
A hammer
A sword
And claws 

Yup. This game got 5 f*king weapons. The only difference is that there are multiple types of each weapon, just not in a good way.
It's literally just default axe but with poison damage added, or default axe with higher damage, default axe that gives mana when hitting enemies, default axe that makes you wish this game had actual weapon variety.
None of these have different movesets or animations, just a different sprite and a (de)buff for each different type. Repeat this for all weapons.
The end result is that the game only has 5 weapons.

2. COTL dungeon runs are extremely short: only 5-15 minutes per run depending on which area you pick.
This is neither a positive or a negative itself, the issue comes from that you spend so much more time prepping for the dungeon run than the actual dungeon run itself, this is especially the case in the endgame.

3. I must first note that the game is controller recommended, but there is straightup zero reason in the gameplay that would indicate keyboard users to be inferior to controller users in this game, given that the game actually functions properly..
I don't bloody know how but for some reason the character often rolls in a completely arbitrary direction, I really hope this does not exist for controller users. 
Furthermore I often seem to get hit for no reason mid-roll immunity frames as well somehow.
These 2 combined are the cause of 70% of all damage I take in this game, causing the dungeon crawling to be BLOOD BOILINGLY INFURIATING at times.
The combat itself is also very simple to the point of almost being boring.

Finally, the game continues after the default ending where you reach your main goal in the story. Neat I guess. Sadly it is done in such a way I was genuinely unsure if it was a true continuation of the story or if it was just a massive amount of bonus content, a new game + of some type perhaps.
And because I avoid spoilers like the plague in games (and also because I am a completionist), I decided to grind to the end of it.
The issue arises that it marks the halfway point of the game when you start it and the game heavily implies there is a great reward at the end of it all, I expected a true ending of a sort.
The way it is done is by literally locking away all your dungeon progress and the game telling you to beat all dungeons in the game over again from start. There is straightup near 0 new content.
The final reward of doing nearly the entire game over again is a complete letdown as well, pretty much coming down to "you did the thing" The end.

There are more minor negatives I would like to list but this review is already too damn long.

Hot damn am I close to flipping this to a negative review now I wrote all of this out, maybe I will one day. For now it stays barely positive though.

Only buy this game at a heavy discount and if the gimmick really interests you.
Final verdict: a low 6/10, maybe a medium/high 6/10 if you are a controller user and really interested in the cult gimmick.

This game is just too much fun. Dare I say, you have to be a little sick and twisted to truly appreciate a game like this. Don't let the cute graphics fool you...this game has blood, gore, death, poop, vomit, supernatural beings, demons, monsters, tarot cards, an upcoming sex update, and decisions that will have you question your sanity. Did I REALLY just murder a follower in the middle of the night for becoming elderly? Yes...yes I did. Your followers are adorable, but don't get attached to them. Some of them may not last long or they will randomly get killed or leave your cult. This game is like Supernatural meets Hello Kitty. I won't spoil the story or the major surprises, so I'll just talk about the gameplay.
 
  The combat is super easy to get used to and the different weapons and curses keep it interesting. I like it when games play different every single time with random dungeon generations, different items, enemies, rewards, etc. The different areas that you can visit are fun and add a nice touch to the game. The boss fights aren't too difficult and if they are, you can scale back the difficulty. I appreciate the fact that this game has a ton of accessibility options, such as auto cook, auto fish, dyslexic friendly texts, and a dark mode option for the main screen. Good on the game devs for keeping everyone in mind, I respect that. 

  If you like fun beat em ups, supernatural/cult stuff, and making lots of decisions, then I highly recommend this game. If you don't think you can bring yourself to make cute animals kill and eat each other, throw them in prison, or do anything that a cult leader would do to their followers, then maybe skip this title. As for me, I own this on Steam AND Nintendo Switch because I can't get enough of it. Everyone, put your hoods up, light your candles, gather up your bones, and get ready to be a cult leader!!
Such a fun and cute game. It's still getting free content updates too, so I'm looking forward to see how this game develops going forward!

[h2]Introduction[/h2]

Cult of the Lamb is greater than the sum of its parts. It doesn't quite achieve rogue-like or base-building legendary status, but the overall package is elevated higher than its reach.

[h2]Story[/h2]

You're a lamb sacrificed by four gods named "the bishops of old faith." Upon death, you meet an imprisoned fifth bishop named "The One Who Waits." The One Who Waits provides a crown embued with godly powers, tasks you to start a cult in his name, and kill the other four bishops.

The story is a simple one, but I never felt I wanted more. It's a solid foundation for satirical humor, and the religious references are funny and land often.

As things progress the game rewards you with little tidbits about your origin and place among the bishops. It's all light fare and works well.

[h2]Gameplay[/h2]

I didn't know I needed a genre blend of rogue-like, bullet-hell combat combined with the progression of a base-builder, but it's a beautiful balance.

Combining these genres creates a nice pace where you do a dungeon run to collect resources and hurry home to take care of your followers. The flow is reinforced by a daily timer prominently displayed at all times. I also appreciated how your cult's base progression advances combat strength. Outside of combat and base building is a variety of minigames, including fishing, a gambling dice-based game, and other cults to visit and exploit.

[h2]Base Building and Your Cult[/h2]

The gameplay is fun and addicting but never very deep.

There are familiar elements like resource gathering to build new structures and you can refine resources to create more advanced structures.

You need to farm to feed your growing cult and use their feces to fertilize new crops. If followers get hungry or unhappy for any reason, they will dissent and start spreading ant-gospel to everyone else. You can then imprison them until they learn to behave or sacrifice them for meat to feed followers.

Followers level up, and you can send them on adventures to get resources or bring back new people to indoctrinate.

There is the ability to customize every follower's appearance and there are endless unlockable decorations to personalize your base.

The base-building gameplay loop is tied to the cycle of a new day. Each day resets cooldowns like sermons and rituals. Both sermons and rituals boost cult morale. However, rituals have special effects like making everyone feel full for a couple of days, motivated to work tirelessly through the night, or building extra devotion by marrying a follower (wed multiple if you want but they'll get jealous when they witness you smooch another.) You can then extract devotion to level up combat abilities or unlock new structures.

Base progression is well done, and I liked how advanced structures automated farming and other mundane tasks. I was growing bored of some repetitive tasks right around the time I unlocked structures that let my cult do it for me. Nothing is overly complex or overstays it's welcome.

[h2]Adventuring and Killing in the Name of Your God[/h2]

As with base-building, the combat part is also pretty simple. There is a spammable weapon attack, a dodge-roll, a resource-based magic ability, and a charge attack that uses the same magic resource but at a slower rate.

There are several weapon types, such as daggers, swords, axes, and heavy hammers. The only change in gameplay from weapons is attack speed, damage, and how long you're left open after an attack. 

Weapons can also have a single modifier type. There is nothing too crazy here with the usual assortment of poison, crits, health-leeching, or the chance to spawn a little ghost that will attack a nearby enemy. All the modifiers play the same and only add more random damage that the player doesn't control. The crit weapons always give the most bonus and make other options feel trivial.

Enemies range in size, speed, and attack patterns. They flash a moment before they attack. You can dodge-roll at any time and even when charging up your own attack. Other enemies spew projectiles on the screen in bullet-hell fashion.

Your first priority is to avoid damage. Watch for the spew of bullets and enemy charge attacks. Next, get in as much damage as you can. Each weapon has a combo string, with the final hit doing a nice bit of extra damage. The slower the weapon, the shorter the string. There are also charge attacks, but I never found them to be an efficient use of your magic resource.
There are a bunch of magic cooldowns with various ranges and functionality like AOE pushbacks, long-range seeking missiles, and temporary invincibility. The resource requirement is well-tuned, and abilities feel powerful but not overpowered.

The combat loop is fast and fun, if rarely challenging for the seasoned player of these genres. 

[h2]Graphics[/h2]

Cult of the Lamb lives on its presentation and deservedly so. You can't go wrong with cute animals and satanic overtones. Every sprite is lovingly crafted and often hilarious. The animations are excellent, too. I never grew tired of watching Lambert open his cult bible, hover in the air, and extract every bit of devotion from his followers.

There is a large cast of characters and places to see other than your own base and the procedural dungeons. One favorite was a town where the cult leader was obsessed with gold and all things shiny. All his followers were dipped in melted gold and could only shake to acknowledge his presence.

[h2]Sound[/h2]

The music is catchy and memorable. I liked the sound effects, too. With any base-building game, you're bound to hear the same blips and beeps over and over. The effects were always crispy and satisfying. There is no voice acting, but the animalese-like chatter is themed to each character. The spider has a SssSss to his voice, and the fish has an underwater blooping to his tone. The voices always made me laugh.

[h2]Conclusion[/h2]

Cult of the Lamb is a smart game with tons of features and ideas going for it. That said, it plays things safe. The base building is approachable but too simple and one step away from greatness. The combat is good but never as exhilarating as some of its rogue-like peers. However, the presentation and humor are excellent and make Cult of the Lamb feel special enough not to be missed.

[h2]Pros[/h2]
[list]
[*]Genuinely funny
[*]Great pacing and blending of genres
[*]Fun, addicting, and doesn't overstay its welcome
[/list]
[h2]Cons[/h2]
[list]
[*]Combat would benefit from more variety
[*]Base-building remains essentially the same from hour one to hour twenty
[/list]

[h2]Challenge[/h2]

I played the game on "Very Hard." There are several levels of difficulty that adjust how much health you have, how much damage you take, and how quickly your followers get hungry or sick. I found the game relatively easy and desired a bit more challenge. The final encounters were fantastic and a great example of what's possible within the game's framework; I just wish there was more of it.

[h2]Hardware[/h2]
Steam Deck

[h2]Time Played[/h2]
22 hours

[h2]Final Score[/h2]
[b]8/10[/b]

My genre 10/10 benchmark to asses my final score is Hades for the combat side. I don't have much base-building experience, and this is one of the best games I've played in the genre.

When I launched this game for the first time, I played it non-stop for like 7 hours stright, which hasn't happened to me for several years at this point. This game is VERY addictive, and you can easily see why: the animations are satisfying, the colors are lush, the whole gameplay loop of running through dungeons and bringing stuff back to build your settlement just feels so smooth and natural. The settlement shenanigans quickly become the more important part, given that they lead to more of both upgrades and fun moments, but the combat segments don't feel lackluster either, they are pretty fun and challenging at times. The game doesn't go too deep with its systems, but the main story isn't long enought for this to take a toll on the experience. The only gripe I have with the game is the fact that some combat strategies seem obviously inferior to others. It feels like some of the weapons and spells simply exist to dillute otherwise a very powerful loot pool so that you don't constantly get fireballs and crit weapons to plow your way through the rooms. This power level divergence is a necessary measure, but I still feel like the weapon/spell pools could use some tweaks so that discrepancy isn't between getting the better or worse stuff, but rather getting stuff that significantly alters your playstyle in a way that is still viable. The game is otherwise fantastic, and it is super engaging all up until you beat the final boss. This is when the post game content starts, and it gets kinda repetitive/grindy, as you essentially repeat everything you've done in the main plot but with a difficulty modifier. I feel like counting the post-game content as a full-fledged downside would be unfair, but I cannot just omit it either. Overall this is a great pick if making sacrifices to the eldrich gods while cute animals shit all over the place seems like your type of pastime

Cult of the Lamb is an adorable little roguelite with base building elements that sees the main character clearing dungeons on his main quest whilst recruiting new cult members to join his commune.  This is the first roguelite that I have obtained all of the achievements for and I would say it is a good entry point for other achievement hunters that may not be familiar with the genre, such as how I am not overly familiar with the genre or have the reaction times down yet for more difficult games of the genre.  Cult of the Lamb does have a few challenging achievements, such as killing all of the bosses without taking damage or completing a row in purgatory, which is essentially the post game dungeon runs of back to back dungeons and bosses in a single run.  I would give the achievement difficulty a 6/10 because of the purgatory mode and no hit bosses and there are a few missable achievements to watch out for, such as the achievement for winning a game of Knucklebones against each NPC that stands around the table.

Be sure to check out my curator page for more achievement based reviews!

This is a fantastic game and I would highly recommend it for anyone. 

Setting up and looking after the cult back at the base is rewarding and fun! The followers start off not much better than actual infants when it comes to looking after themselves. It can be as amusing and endearing. At moments it can also be frustrating coming home to poop everywhere - but now I look back fondly on my days of tending to my early followers poop!

The crusading has a brilliant combat system, and is very beginner friendly if you haven't played many roguelike games like this one before. The story was really compelling to unravel too, and the breaks between story arcs and tending to the cult were very cleverly structured. 

One thing I wish was in the game... without trying to spoiler anything, my dumb fingers managed to misname a character in my cult who is very important to me and now I can't change it and they're stuck like that D:

My own mistake of course! But whenever I see them now a little part of me internally is yelling 'noooo!' I wish it would be possible to have a renaming function? I've seen this mentioned online and suggestions of a few different ways to implement it so thankfully I'm not alone in pressing the wrong button! 

The cult menu when pressing - doesn't seem to actually do much of anything right now. Would be awesome to have that feature in there. Or maybe a ritual which allows you to reset the name and attributes of a follower to hopefully roll for better traits? Might be quite useful for later game...

I'm so sad I didn't play it in time to vote for the 'Labor of Love' award! It really has earned it - there is so much heart and personality bursting from this game. Can't wait to see what comes next!

I hope everyone enjoys this game as much as I have!!! <3

[h1] Cult of the Lamp [/h1]

Is it bold to deem this is as my all-time currently favourite rogue-lite? Honestly, I'm a little unsure.
Straight-up I'm no rogue-lite nor rogue-like fan, I don't like the formula nor the ideology behind the genre for the most part. While there are a few games within the genre I've managed to enjoy a little, sort-term; mostly -- Cult of the Lamb however is however the first one I've managed to enjoy for more than 2-or-so hours, which is very impressive to my standards.
If you're interested to hear about my personal problems with the rogue genre, specifically the rogue-lite genre, you're welcome to check out my Hades review! Thank you.

But I really enjoyed Cult of the Lamb. I may never have finished it, nor do I imagine myself ever doing so... Not because it's "too hard" or anything, I just eventually got bored & unmotivated.
Still, I quite enjoyed the majority of my time with this game.



[h1] Rogue-lite [/h1]

As previously stated, if you're interested in hearing a more in-depth opinion on the rogue-lite formula you should check-out my Hades review.
However Cult of the Lamb truly stands out, it really stands apart from the others in the genre. I can really praise that, especially as my biggest gripe with the genre is the formulaic & stereotypical; untouched ideology behind all the games. Maybe there's some other rogue-lite game I don't know about which also changes it a tad, but I don't know & all the majour ones don't.

But it really strikes out & carves its own path using the bare definitions of rogue-lites. It plays itself much like Animal Crossing x Hades; and those are 2 games I've really somewhat enjoyed. Yet their combination just seem to work so flawlessly here.
The rogue-lite pieces seem to not be the main attraction here, but instead only be half of the puzzle pieces to the entire jigsaw puzzle. It works in conjunction alongside the cult management to fulfill the entire set, and each piece seem to smoothly transition into another largely seamlessly.
And I mainly focused on the cult parts of the game, as that's what I enjoyed the most. I really enjoyed building up this little town for my members, and decorating it very nicely, and pleasing my cult members. All very satisfying, all very cool. I truly enjoyed the resource-management part of this game. I felt like I constantly was running out of materials, and then had to gather some by going through the rogue-lite doors to gather materials & villagers to turn cult members. It's a truly cool system, as I've been starving for a twist in the formulaic & copy-paste formula of rogue-lite games. So when the rogue-lite parts aren't treated as a constant grind to beat the game, but only as a occasional grind for loots; with an end-goal set around beating the game. For most of the game, once you walk into a rogue-lite door it's not because you want to beat the game, because the majority of the doors don't allow that. The doors are split up into 5, and 4 of them you need to grind through multiple times individually to even unlock the last one. Entering the previous 4 doors after beating them are not necessary to beat the game, as such repeating areas you've already mastered are not mandatory. Take some f#cking notes, Hades.
And one of my favourite features are the fact that even if you die, you don't lose all your loot -- only a percentage. This means that even if you mess up, and die, you didn't just dedicate yourself to some 30 minute "nothing-burger" run, where all you achieved were some arbitrary upgrades for your next attempts... no. Instead you get the materials which you can actually use outside of the rogue-lite aspects of the game to build your town up. Amazing!
And it's even better by the fact that your weapons are basically 100% randomized. You can never rely on a singular weapon, as you're always pushed into enforced use of a weapon you maybe haven't learnt yet or feel comfortable with; so that you can get out of your comfort-zone & learn other play-styles... again... take some f#cking notes, Hades.

I consider this game the 'Hades successor'. Not only does the "hub" area actually mean something, but failed runs does too. This game is just really perfect, truly.



[h1] Conclusion [/h1]

I really enjoyed Cult of the Lamb. I had low hopes for this game, I only played it because I wanted to hate it... but surprisingly, I didn't.
The only probable actual criticism I have for the game is that the music is somewhat lame, and doesn't fit with the game very often. It also gets very stale & repetitive. But don't worry, it's nowhere near as bad as something like God of War 2018's lame-ass soundtrack.

I really hope more future rogue-lite games copy the ideology of Cult of the Lamb, without copying its formula too. Rogue-lites deserve some actual changes, and to experience the uniqueness other majour genres do.
I'm deeply grateful for Cult of the Lamb, and I have a lot of respect for it too.
I'm sad that played so much upon release that I essentially burn myself out, as I've basically lost all my will to play for now.
Still, I can't wait to get back into it once I get the will to do so once more!

Elder gods decide to sacrifice you. They make a sacrificial lamb of you. Ironically, you are literally a lamb. But not the one who resigned themselves to their fate. Luck in the form of the enemy of elders gods saved you from a tragic final. Now you are alive, dangerous, and ready to take revenge. The only thing is to get strong enough to challenge the enemies. To do that, you need followers who give you what you seek. With the help of a supernatural patron, you will run your cult and kill elders gods.

It`s how your Cult of Lamb will be started (or not "Cult of Lamb"‚Äîit's yours; you can give it whatever name you like). And it`s up to you how your cult will finish. The adventure of the little cultist lamb has started.

The game provides us with two main mechanics. First is the cult builder sim. You manage your village, look after followers, build buildings, hold ceremonies, etc. Second is rouge-like dungeon rides called ‚ÄúCrusade‚Äù. You collect resources, get new followers, and, of course, defeat bosses. Also, there are mini-games and some interesting mechanics which make the game process deeper. All of these things combine ideally you don`t have a chance to be bored (maybe a bit with a village). Tired of building a village - move to crusade, tired of dungeons - your followers are awaiting. Switching mechanics imperceptibly moves you to the game final, providing a lot of joy. What else provides joy is the game style. I`m sure Cult of Lamb developers hardly see this review, however, I need to say that the character design and visuals are terrific. Your designers are rocks. Characters look not only cute but also scary. Which is not so easy to achieve, obviously.

Cult of Lamb is practically devoid of cons. Someone might say modest duration is the main minus of the game. But developers works on that and the latest update provides us with additional quests after beating the last boss. So I would say the major con is not addictive base-building mechanics. Yes, it`s good to get rest from the crusade by building a village but it might be much more interesting if we have some reasons to improve the cult, except to be stronger on crusades. Or to build a more posh-looking village.

However if you are fan of unusual settings, not trivial ideas and rouge-lite games choosing Cult of Lamb would be great idea!  Be sure to try

I originally started playing Cult of the Lamb on the Nintendo Switch (before going to PC gaming). I never did finish the game on the Switch (I get side tracked so easily) but do prefer it on the PC over the other system. I have yet to try it on my steam deck but since it's recommended to use a controller versus mouse and keyboard I'm going to assume it plays just fine. If you enjoy cozy games and cute spooky elements then I believe you'll like it. The bosses are a bit challenging but fun and when you aren't going on crusades you can fish, give sermons to your "followers", farm, cook, etc. Overall, it's a pretty fun game; and plus the devs release updates and DLCs off and on.

Having said that, I'm not a big fan of rogue-lite because I often find the games a bit too difficult or the fact that you have to dash 75 times to hit a mob and the fact that it's really punishing. But, in cult of the lamb the game is just a mix of hack n' slash and combat that you have to think about your attack and dash. And the fact that the game is well scaled, I feel like giving the rogue genre another chance. 

I've seen a couple of reviews and some people seem to be saying that the fights are too simple or that you can abuse certain mechanics. But if you play the game and don't really think about pushing the big min-max game, you're going to have a really nice ride.

I wasn't sure what to expect when I started this game.  I had it recommended by a friend.  I am very glad that I took up the recommendation.  There is a lot of meat to this game, and to my surprise there is quite a bit to complete after you beat the final story boss also.  You have city building/management aspects and the adventure portion of the game kind of plays out like an old school top down Zelda game.  The game play is very addicting and is one of those types of games where "one more run" keeps you up until after midnight.  There are some rogue-lite qualities as there are permanent upgrades with random generated maps.  There really isn't that harsh of a penalty when you die except that the faith of your cult may be lowered, but it is easy enough to bring back up without being frustrated.  

Awesome game.  A solid 9 which I'm planning on finishing 100%.

Title: "Cult of the Lamb: A Divine Blend of Cute and Quirky"

Rating: ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ (5/5)

Step into the enchanting world of Cult of the Lamb, where adorable creatures, cultish endeavors, and a quirky sense of humor come together in a delightfully bizarre package. This roguelike action-adventure from Massive Monster manages to strike a balance between challenge and charm, earning its stripes in the indie gaming realm.

The game introduces players to an unexpected protagonist‚Äîan adorable lamb who finds themselves at the center of an eccentric cult. The premise alone sets the stage for the kind of quirky adventure you didn't know you needed. The pixel art style, combined with whimsical characters, creates an atmosphere that's both cute and strangely captivating.

Gameplay in Cult of the Lamb is where the magic truly happens. The roguelike elements ensure that each run feels fresh, challenging players to navigate through procedurally generated dungeons while mastering the art of combat. The combination of precision and strategy keeps you on your toes, making each playthrough a delightful dance between chaos and control.

Now, let's address the cheeky suggestion of a "Sex Update" that could allegedly elevate the rating to a mythical 6/5 stars. While the idea adds a humorous twist to the review, it's important to appreciate that Cult of the Lamb's charm lies in its quirky, family-friendly appeal. However the idea of a "Sex Update" would definitely be an addition that would have players enjoying themselves for hours longer with their Cult Followers especially if including the Twitch Integration with your followers and viewers on Twitch.

In conclusion, Cult of the Lamb earns a solid five-star rating for its imaginative concept, engaging gameplay, and the sheer joy it brings to the indie gaming scene. While the idea of a "Sex Update" might be tongue-in-cheek, it's essential to recognize and celebrate the game's existing strengths without veering into territories that could compromise its wholesome charm. So, whether you're a seasoned gamer or just looking for a dose of cute chaos, Cult of the Lamb is a divine experience that's worth every pixel.
